name: kailash ranganathan
short_description: EECS student at UC Berkeley with diverse research experience in ML systems, hardware acceleration, quantum computing, and reinforcement learning. Currently a GPU Architecture Intern at NVIDIA and researcher at Berkeley AI Research, focusing on generalizable methods in reinforcement learning.
long_description:
Kailash Ranganathan is an Electrical Engineering and Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with a multidisciplinary focus spanning machine learning systems, hardware acceleration, statistical physics, quantum computing, and reinforcement learning.

His professional experience includes a current position as a GPU Architecture Intern at NVIDIA, where he works on cutting-edge graphics processing technology. Simultaneously, he conducts research at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) in the RAIL (Robotic AI & Learning) lab, focusing on generalizable methods in reinforcement learning. The RAIL lab's mission is to enable machines to exhibit flexible and adaptable behavior, acquired autonomously through learning.

Kailash's research portfolio is impressively diverse. At UC Berkeley's Quantum Devices Group, he investigates superconducting qubits, surface piezoelectricity, and microwave engineering. Previously, he interned at Analog Devices, where he worked on increasing power efficiency for ML hardware accelerators. His experience also includes FPGA programming for laser cavity stabilization at Berkeley Lab and software engineering at Beacon AI, where he developed aircraft performance modeling and route planning solutions.

Beyond his technical research, Kailash is actively involved in student organizations at Berkeley. He serves as a socials chair for the Society of Physics Students (SPS) alongside Shaurya Jain, helping to build community among physics students. He is also a member of Launchpad, a community of problem solvers focused on tackling challenges with machine learning and artificial intelligence.

His academic background includes coursework in deep reinforcement learning, computer science fundamentals, electrical engineering, physics, and mathematics, including specialized courses in quantum algorithms for scientific computing. Before Berkeley, he attended The Harker School, where he took advanced courses in multivariable calculus, differential equations, nonlinear dynamics, signals and systems, neural networks, and computer architecture.

Kailash's unique combination of expertise in both theoretical physics and practical ML engineering positions him at the intersection of quantum computing and artificial intelligence, two fields with transformative potential in the coming decades.

name: rez havaei
short_description: Rez Havaei is the CEO & Co-Founder of General Analysis (YC S24), a startup developing automated AI safety and red-teaming tools. With expertise in AI research and quantitative trading, his career includes roles at Cohere, NVIDIA, Jane Street, and as a founding engineer at vals.ai, where he helped build an LLM evaluation platform.
long_description:
Rez Havaei is an accomplished entrepreneur and AI specialist currently serving as the CEO & Co-Founder of General Analysis, a Y Combinator-backed startup (S24 batch) focused on AI safety and evaluation. The company provides a comprehensive suite of tools for identifying and addressing vulnerabilities in AI systems, including red-teaming frameworks and interpretability techniques.

General Analysis was founded in 2024 and is based in San Francisco. The company's mission is to address the growing risks associated with deploying increasingly capable AI systems in high-stakes environments. Their approach involves developing automated tools that systematically find model failure modes and enhance model robustness, delivering detailed safety and performance reports to customers.

One of their notable projects demonstrated how GPT-4o is susceptible to hallucinating when asked about legal cases or concepts. Their research showed they could train an attacker model that caused GPT-4o to hallucinate on more than 35% of prompts related to legal questions.

Before founding General Analysis, Rez worked as a founding engineer at vals.ai, where he helped build an LLM evaluation platform and benchmark. This startup, co-founded by Stanford AI students, aimed to create a standardized test for measuring artificial intelligence and large language models, providing an unbiased, third-party review system.

Rez's professional experience spans both AI research and finance. He has worked as an Applied Research Intern in Deep Learning at Snap Inc., a Machine Learning Engineering Intern at Cohere (a leading AI company developing large language models), and held an Applied Research position in Artificial Intelligence at NVIDIA. His finance background includes quantitative trading internships at prestigious firms like Jane Street and Susquehanna International Group (SIG).

His academic research experience includes positions at the USC Information Sciences Institute and as a Research Assistant at UC Davis, where he also served as a Teaching Assistant. Rez earned a Bachelor of Science in Engineering from the University of California, Davis (2018-2023), maintaining a 3.97 GPA.

Rez is also involved in another venture called Kart AI, which serves as an interactive search platform that simplifies research for electronic products. The platform extracts relevant recommendations from Reddit, YouTube, and trusted content creators to help users find and compare electronic products.

His technical interests and expertise span AI safety, interpretability, evaluation, deep learning, and statistical inference. Rez's career trajectory demonstrates his commitment to addressing the challenges of AI safety and evaluation while building practical tools that can help organizations deploy AI systems more responsibly.

name: anush mutyala
short_description: Anush Mutyala is a biomedical engineering student at UBC and multifaceted researcher working at the intersection of neuroscience, robotics, and hardware engineering. Currently developing calibration-free robotics at NC4 Lab while building electronics for STEM cell factories at General Cybernetics, he's also passionate about DIY semiconductor fabrication and neuromorphic computing.
long_description:
Anush Mutyala is a biomedical engineering student at the University of British Columbia, attending on a prestigious $120,000 Schulich Leader Scholarship. His research interests span multiple cutting-edge domains, with a particular focus on neuromorphic computing, robotics, and hardware engineering.

Currently, Anush works as a Robotics Researcher at NC4 Lab, where he's developing neural manifold approaches to eliminate sensor calibration in robotics systems. His work involves building ROS/Gazebo simulations to generate rich LIDAR datasets. Simultaneously, he serves as an Electrical Engineering Intern at General Cybernetics, designing PCBs for bioelectric cell reprogramming experiments using LTSpice and Altium/Kicad.

Anush's research background is impressively diverse. At York University's LCRAIN lab, he led a cross-institutional team developing bio-plausible spiking neural network training algorithms using EEG-fMRI data. At the University of Toronto's Intelligent Sensory Microsystems Lab, he integrated spiking neural networks into low-power neural implants, reducing latency by 5x through algorithmic optimizations while enabling wearable form factors. He also designed gate-level implementations on FPGA to support future ASIC/tape-out efforts.

His entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his co-founding of NeuraDAO, which aimed to create a democratized funding ecosystem for neuroscience and technology research. The project raised over $6,000 in Gitcoin Round 15 and involved developing a decentralized marketplace for neuroimaging datasets built on Web3 protocols.

Anush has also contributed to consumer neurotechnology at Divergence Neuro, where he helped build an EEG-based neurofeedback therapy platform, working on visualization modules and event-related potential experiments.

His innovation in neural implant technology has gained recognition, winning a bronze excellence award at the Canada-Wide Science Fair in 2023 for his project "Enerspike." This algorithm dramatically improves battery life in neural implants by optimizing power usage, potentially extending battery lifespan by up to 70 times and eliminating the need for surgical replacement every few years. The project was inspired by both Elon Musk's Neuralink and Stephen Hawking's vision of brain-computer interfaces as the future of communication.

Beyond his formal roles, Anush is passionate about DIY semiconductor fabrication, having received an Emergent Ventures Fellowship grant to build a maskless photolithography stepper for Hacker Fab at UBC. His team was also a finalist at Hack The North 2022 with the project "ConnexSci," which used Graph Neural Networks to optimize drug discovery.

Anush represents a new generation of interdisciplinary researchers working at the convergence of neuroscience, electrical engineering, and artificial intelligence, with a particular focus on developing energy-efficient, brain-inspired computing systems and their applications in healthcare and robotics.

name: vineeth vajipey
short_description: Vineeth Vajipey is an NLP Researcher and MS CS student at Columbia University specializing in natural language processing and AI agents. With experience in autonomous vehicles and machine learning research, he has contributed to the field through his work on exploratory learning for AI agents and has won multiple hackathon awards including Overall 1st Place at PennApps.
long_description:
Vineeth Vajipey is a Master of Science student in Computer Science at Columbia University, specializing in Natural Language Processing. Currently working as an NLP Researcher at Columbia's Speech and Dialog Lab, he is advised by Xiao Yu, Qingyang Wu, and Zhou Yu, focusing on research related to Large Language Models (LLMs) and AI agents.

His academic journey includes a Bachelor of Science degree from the University of Maryland, where he graduated with an impressive 3.98/4.0 GPA. During his undergraduate years, he was involved in various research initiatives including FIRE: Capital One Machine Learning, RAAS Lab, and Gomez Lab. He also contributed to education as a Teaching Assistant for ENEE205/101 and as an instructor for CMSC389F STIC.

Vineeth's professional experience spans across diverse organizations. He is currently interning as a Software Engineer at The D. E. Shaw Group (May 2024 - Aug 2024). Previously, he worked as a Software Engineer at Swingtech for nearly three years (Aug 2021 - May 2024). His research experience includes roles as an Autonomous Vehicles Researcher at Istanbul Technical University (Summer 2023) and as a Machine Learning Researcher at Maryland Robotics Center (Summer 2022). He also completed a Software Engineering internship at CB Insights in Summer 2021.

His research contributions include a significant publication titled "Improving Autonomous AI Agents with Reflective Tree Search and Self-Learning" (also known as "ExACT: Teaching AI Agents to Explore with Reflective-MCTS and Exploratory Learning"), which was accepted at the International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR). This work, co-authored with researchers including Xiao Yu, Baolin Peng, Hao Cheng, Michel Galley, Jianfeng Gao, and Zhou Yu, introduces Reflective Monte Carlo Tree Search (R-MCTS), a novel algorithm designed to enhance AI agents' ability to explore decision spaces. The research has garnered attention in the field, with multiple citations since its publication.

Another notable publication is "GATSBI: An online GTSP-based algorithm for targeted surface bridge inspection," which demonstrates his work in robotics and autonomous systems.

Vineeth has demonstrated exceptional skills in hackathons, winning Overall 1st Place and the Wolfram Research Award at PennApps Fall 2023 for a project called CharactAR, an augmented reality customizable chat companion. He also placed 4th Overall at PennApps Fall 2020 with Air Synth and won Best Hack for Resilience at PennApps Fall 2019 with Prophet Profit.

During his undergraduate years at the University of Maryland, Vineeth was recognized for his creativity and innovation. He developed various projects including an app for a smart vending machine with facial recognition, a device that adjusts the brightness and color of lights based on hand gestures, and a game where musicians guess musical notes. He also contributed to developing a software platform for a waste management company in India, integrating thousands of informal recyclers into the supply chain to help cities manage waste more effectively.

His diverse experience across software engineering, research in NLP, autonomous vehicles, and machine learning, combined with his academic excellence and hackathon achievements, showcases his versatility and innovative approach to solving complex problems in the field of artificial intelligence.

name: janos meny
short_description: Janos Meny is a mathematician turned programmer specializing in geometry processing, optimization, and computer graphics. Currently working at Roblox on realtime solid modeling tools, he previously developed implicit modeling solutions at nTop for 3D printing applications.
long_description:
Janos Meny is a mathematician who transitioned into programming, with expertise in geometry processing, optimization, and computer graphics. He completed his education at the University of Bonn, where he studied mathematics with a focus on algebraic geometry during his bachelor's degree and PDE-constrained optimization for his master's.

Currently, Janos works at Roblox where he develops realtime, fully networked solid modeling tools and geometry processing algorithms. Prior to joining Roblox, he was employed at nTop, where he worked on implicit modeling and latticing tools specifically designed for high-performance 3D printing applications.

His professional interests span multiple technical domains including computational geometry, computer graphics, numerical optimization, robotics, compilers, programming languages, and applied mathematics. This multidisciplinary approach is evident in his project portfolio, which includes:

- Mantis: A high-performance, SIMD-accelerated implementation for computing distance to triangle mesh
- Phasefield: A phasefield-based optimization framework for 3D surface segmentation

Janos's background in computational fluid dynamics (CFD) and his engagement with GPU-native technologies demonstrates his expertise in high-performance computing applications. His consistent interest in additive manufacturing and 3D printing technologies is reflected in his professional work at nTop, where he developed solutions for advanced manufacturing processes.

His unique combination of mathematical theory and practical programming skills positions him at the intersection of theoretical computer science and applied engineering, allowing him to contribute to cutting-edge developments in real-time geometry processing and modeling tools.

name: natnael kahssay
short_description: Computer Science and Engineering student at MIT with a unique blend of hardware expertise spanning RF systems, FPGA design, and nano-fabrication. Founder of Saverntronics technologies and researcher in bioelectronics, Natnael combines hands-on engineering with entrepreneurial vision.
long_description:
Natnael Kahssay is a Computer Science and Engineering student at MIT with an impressive breadth of technical expertise across hardware domains. His background spans RF systems, FPGA design, nano-fabrication, and hardware design, with proficiency in programming languages including Bluespec, C, and Python, as well as industry tools like Cadence and Vivado.

As an undergraduate researcher in MIT's Bioelectronics Group, Natnael works on cutting-edge optogenetic-based waveguide and neural implants used to study stress in addiction susceptibility, demonstrating his ability to apply engineering principles to neuroscience research. His academic contributions extend to teaching roles, where he serves as a Laboratory Teaching Assistant for Digital System Laboratory I (6.205), helping students implement digital design projects on Sparta-7 FPGAs.

Natnael's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his founding of Saverntronics technologies, where he led the development of an autonomous barbing machine, handling both digital modeling and actuator response characterization. This venture showcases his ability to take technical concepts from ideation to implementation.

His project portfolio reflects his diverse interests, including work on an 802.11a Physical layer on RFSoC, Nano MEMS Mirrors, and various software projects. On GitHub, he maintains several open-source projects, including "gestures" (a fluid gestures system for Linux with 68 stars), and extensions for GNOME window management. His GitHub profile, where he goes by "natask," emphasizes his philosophy that "Productivity is key. Planning is essential."

Natnael has also contributed to significant academic projects, including an HFT (High-Frequency Trading) Accelerator developed with his brother Endrias Kahssay and teammate Ziheng Wang as part of MIT's 6.111 (Digital Systems Laboratory) final project in Fall 2019. This project demonstrated his ability to work on complex, time-sensitive computational systems.

Currently, Natnael is set to join Etched, indicating his continued trajectory in the technology sector. His multidisciplinary background at the intersection of computer science, electrical engineering, and bioelectronics positions him uniquely in the field of hardware engineering and design.

name: zifei xu
short_description: Zifei Xu is a Senior Machine Learning Research Engineer at d-Matrix, specializing in AI inference acceleration. With a PhD in Fluid and Machinery Engineering, a Master's in Computational and Mathematical Engineering from Stanford, and experience as a Marie Curie Research Fellow at the University of Liverpool, she combines strong technical expertise in machine learning with practical engineering skills. Her research spans LLM quantization, intelligent fault diagnostics, and offshore wind turbine technologies.
long_description:
Zifei Xu is a Senior Machine Learning Research Engineer at d-Matrix, where she focuses on developing cutting-edge solutions for AI inference acceleration. Her work contributes to d-Matrix's mission of making generative AI more efficient and accessible through specialized hardware and software optimizations, with particular expertise in post-training quantization of large language models.

With a diverse educational background, Zifei holds a PhD in Fluid and Machinery Engineering from the University of Shanghai for Science and Technology (2016-2022), a Master's degree in Computational and Mathematical Engineering with a Data Science track from Stanford University (2021-2023), and a Bachelor of Engineering with Highest Distinction from the National University of Singapore (2016-2020), where she also minored in Computer Science.

Zifei's professional journey spans both industry and academia. Before joining d-Matrix as a Senior ML Research Engineer in July 2023, she completed an internship with the same company, demonstrating her value to the organization. Prior to that, she worked as an IT Engineer specializing in Front End Automation at Micron Technology in Singapore for over a year. Her early career also includes a machinery internship at ExxonMobil, where she worked on machine monitoring and data analysis.

In academia, Zifei has served as a Marie Curie Research Fellow at the University of Liverpool and Liverpool John Moores University (2022-2023), where she conducted research on diagnostics, prognostics, and health management technologies for mechanical systems of floating offshore wind turbines. Her research has been prolific, with over 30 peer-reviewed publications focusing on structural health monitoring, machine learning-based intelligent fault diagnostics, remaining useful life prediction, and mechanical system dynamic modeling.

Her recent research contributions include work on post-training quantization of large language models, self-selected attention span for accelerating LLM inference, and scaling laws for quantized LLMs. She has also applied interpretable machine learning to healthcare domains, including predicting maternal and fetal outcomes.

Zifei's technical credentials include being a speaker at the PyTorch Conference 2024, certification as a Code in Place 2023 Section Leader at Stanford, and completing courses in Neural Networks and Deep Learning, JavaScript web programming, and debugging techniques. She also holds a Solid Edge ST10 Certified Professional credential from Siemens.

Multilingual and with cross-cultural experience, Zifei is proficient in Chinese (Mandarin) and English. Her unique combination of deep technical knowledge in machine learning, practical engineering experience, and interdisciplinary research makes her a valuable contributor to the fields of AI hardware optimization, inference acceleration, and applied machine learning.

name: arjun banerjee
short_description: UC Berkeley student, Head of Education at Launchpad, and Industrial Relations Officer at HKN. Founder and CEO of Kids Teach Tech, a non-profit organization teaching technology to underserved youth.
long_description:
Arjun Banerjee is a student at UC Berkeley with extensive involvement in technology education and leadership. He serves as the Head of Education at Launchpad, a community of problem solvers focused on intelligent software and artificial intelligence, and as an Industrial Relations Officer at Eta Kappa Nu (HKN), the Electrical Engineering and Computer Science honor society.

Most notably, Arjun is the founder and CEO of Kids Teach Tech (KTT), a non-profit organization he started at the age of 10. Under his leadership, KTT has built a team of over 250 youth educators who have taught technology, programming, and AI to more than 8,000 students, primarily from underserved communities in the San Francisco Bay Area. The organization follows a "teach it forward" model, where students become teachers and leaders in their communities.

Arjun has established significant partnerships for KTT with UC Berkeley's IEOR Department, Georgia Tech, and the Urban League of Greater San Francisco Bay Area. Together they deliver the Seth Bonder Summer Program in Computational and Data Science for Engineering, which provides underserved youth with education in computer programming, data science, optimization, artificial intelligence, and computational biology.

His technical expertise spans multiple programming languages, with particular proficiency in Python and C#. Beyond his work with KTT, Arjun has contributed to data visualization projects, including the Ten Strands/CAELI Data Project which won the Fall 2022 Data Visualization Award at UC Berkeley. This project focused on understanding environmental literacy education in California K-12 schools.

Arjun also has experience as a Research Assistant at Stanford University's Hoover Institution, where he developed an interactive archive of declassified documents from the Intelligence Community. His diverse interests extend to national and international policy, philosophy, poetry, and quantum physics.

Dhruv Diddi is an engineer and entrepreneur based in the San Francisco Bay Area with specialized experience in Applied Machine Learning. He is the founder of Solo, a revolutionary platform that brings AI directly to users' devices, ensuring data privacy, personalized experiences, and accessibility without reliance on cloud infrastructure. Solo has particularly focused on healthcare applications, addressing challenges around data privacy (HIPAA compliance), accessibility in low-connectivity environments, and customization for specific healthcare scenarios.

Dhruv actively promotes Solo through his newsletter "Get Solo Tech" on Substack, where he discusses innovations like Solo Health, which aims to transform patient care through on-device AI that protects sensitive patient data while providing robust performance for diagnostics, patient monitoring, and workflow optimization.

As a tech community participant, Dhruv has been featured as a speaker and host at San Francisco tech events, including a panel discussion on "AI + Human Intelligence" where he presented Solo alongside other founders. He's also participated in hackathons, with his profile showing attendance at AI hackathon events.

Dhruv brings a strong educational foundation from the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign where he was recognized as a James Scholar and made the Dean's List. His technical expertise spans multiple domains, including Machine Learning, Algorithms, Computer Architecture (Honors), Data Structures (Honors), Interactive Computer Graphics, and R Programming. His multilingual abilities include native proficiency in English, Hindi, and Punjabi, along with working knowledge of French and Mandarin Chinese.

As an educator, Dhruv has received glowing recommendations for his work as an instructor at General Assembly's boot camp program. Former students praise his patience, extensive knowledge, and ability to break down complex concepts in accessible ways. His teaching style is described as easy-going yet effective, making him a favorite resource for students struggling with difficult concepts.

Dhruv maintains an active presence in the AI and tech community, regularly publishing his newsletter "So Essentially Weekly" that covers developments in the field. His project portfolio demonstrates versatility and practical application of his skills, including work with Illini Hyperloop, a Kaggle Challenge on Titanic Prediction, and various web and mobile applications like Flare, Anthem Web App, and a Dwolla Pebble App.

Dhruv's professional focus appears to be at the intersection of privacy-first AI applications and healthcare innovation, with an emphasis on bringing powerful machine learning capabilities directly to devices while protecting user data and ensuring accessibility regardless of internet connectivity.

short_description: Full stack engineer with expertise in AI/ML, currently working as an ML Engineer Intern at Spot Parking. Ben combines technical skills in machine learning, computer vision, and software development with business strategy acumen, having published research at AAAI and contributed to multiple startups. He is also known as "The Bake King," a renowned cake artist who creates hyper-realistic edible sculptures.
long_description:
Ben Cullen is a versatile full stack engineer with specialized expertise in AI/ML, currently serving as an ML Engineer Intern at Spot Parking where he's working on freeing up parking spaces through machine learning applications. He's pursuing a Computer Science degree with a Data Science emphasis at Brigham Young University, complemented by a minor in Business Strategy.

Ben's professional journey showcases a remarkable breadth of experience across AI and software development. At nCino, he developed features for their AI Assistant to enhance banker efficiency. His work at NEXU involved creating I.A.N., an AI phone platform that reduced referral verification time by 80%. As a Computer Vision Software Engineer at BYU, he achieved 99% accuracy in document layout analysis using image transformers, processing documents 64x faster and generating significant cost savings.

His technical versatility extends to full stack development, demonstrated through his work at ChoiceGuard Insurance Services where he built a HIPAA-compliant onboarding platform, and at Calisto Inc as a Founding Software Engineer, taking the company from zero software to a pilot with a major pest control company in just 5 months.

Ben's academic achievements are equally impressive, maintaining a 3.98 GPA and making the Dean's List four times. He co-authored a research paper published at the prestigious AAAI Conference on enhancing story comprehension for large language models through dynamic document-based knowledge graphs, which improved the quality of AI-generated text by up to 1.9x.

Beyond his tech career, Ben has an entirely separate professional identity as "The Bake King," one of the UK's most celebrated cake artists. He began his artistic journey as a graphic designer after studying Art & Design at Chester University, then worked as a tattoo artist before discovering his passion for creating hyper-realistic cakes. His transition to cake art began in 2014 when he made his first cake for his father, inspired by a design shown to him by a tattoo client's mother.

As The Bake King, Ben has won multiple gold awards at Cake International in 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, and 2019, and was named one of the UK's Top 10 Cake Artists at Cakemasters in 2019. His extraordinary talent for creating life-like edible sculptures has earned him celebrity clients like Rita Ora, appearances on Channel 4's "Extreme Cake Makers," and hundreds of thousands of followers across social media platforms. His work is particularly notable for making objects so realistic that they're often indistinguishable from the real items they represent.

Throughout both of his careers, Ben has demonstrated an exceptional ability to bridge technical innovation with artistic creativity and practical business applications, making him a uniquely versatile professional who excels in both technology and artistic fields.

His software portfolio includes several successful applications: Buseroo.com, which helps students find appropriate school buses; Homework Checker, used by 2,000 students for assignment management; Focus for Google Docs, a productivity tool with 1,000 users; Edit Time, which helps 4,000 users manage file modification properties; and LirongArt.com, a showcase for his mother's artwork.

name: vivek vajipey
short_description: Vivek Vajipey is a Computer Science student at Stanford University pursuing both Bachelor's and Master's degrees with a minor in Geophysics. His research at Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) focuses on reasoning in large language models, while his previous work applied machine learning to agricultural remote sensing. He has developed innovative AI applications including ExplainAI, CriticAL, and WorldDex, winning awards at major hackathons like PennApps XXIV and Cal Hacks 10.0.
long_description:
Vivek Vajipey is pursuing both a Bachelor's and Master's degree in Computer Science at Stanford University, with a minor in Geophysics. His academic journey reflects a deep interest in the intersection of artificial intelligence and practical applications.

At the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL), Vivek researches reasoning capabilities in large language models through the Computation & Cognition Lab. His work in AI extends beyond theoretical research - he has recently co-authored "CriticAL: Critic Automation with Language Models," demonstrating his contribution to advancing LLM technologies.

Vivek has developed several notable AI projects. ExplainAI, a conversational tool that helps users better understand what they're reading, showcases his interest in making AI more accessible and educational. His WorldDex project, described as "a Pokédex for the real world," won the Best Web3 Hack award at Cal Hacks 10.0 by using computer vision and LLMs to identify and interact with real-world objects. He also won first place at PennApps XXIV for developing CharactAR, an interactive experience combining generative AI with augmented reality.

Prior to his current research focus, Vivek worked at Stanford's Lobell Lab applying machine learning techniques to remote sensing data for agricultural applications. This work contributed to a significant publication titled "Annual field-scale maps of tall and short crops at the global scale using GEDI and Sentinel-2," published in Remote Sensing in 2023. As a co-author alongside researchers Stefania Di Tommaso, Sherrie Wang, and others, Vivek helped develop a method that combines NASA's GEDI lidar data with Sentinel-2 satellite imagery to create global maps distinguishing between tall and short crops at 10m resolution. This research has been cited 11 times according to Google Scholar, highlighting its impact in the field of agricultural remote sensing.

His professional experience includes a fellowship at True Ventures and a software engineering role at Swingtech. Within the Stanford community, Vivek served as VP of Events for the Stanford Energy Club, further demonstrating his leadership capabilities and interest in energy-related challenges.

Vivek's academic excellence was evident early in his career when he earned a Silver Medal at the International Earth Science Olympiad, highlighting his aptitude for scientific problem-solving from a young age. His contact email is vvajipey@stanford.edu.

name: andrew tan
short_description: Andrew Tan is a Stanford University alumnus and entrepreneur focused on democratizing career growth. With a strong background in computer science and data science from UC Berkeley, he has conducted research in stock market prediction using sentiment analysis and has been recognized with numerous academic honors including Phi Beta Kappa and the EECS Honors Program.
long_description:
Andrew Tan is an accomplished technologist and entrepreneur currently associated with Humans and Stanford University. He's working on democratizing access to career growth through his venture joinnova.co.

Andrew has an impressive academic background, having graduated from UC Berkeley where he was part of the EECS Honors Program and was inducted into Phi Beta Kappa as a junior (top 20 students in his class). During his time at Berkeley, he excelled as a student instructor in the Data Science Department, earning recognition as an Outstanding Student Instructor.

His research interests include applying AI to financial markets, as evidenced by his publication "Sentiment Predictability for Stocks" where he explored stock market prediction using textual sentiment analysis tools and advanced prediction models like LSTMs and convolutional architectures.

Andrew has a strong entrepreneurial spirit, having been selected for the Pear VC Summer Fellowship which provided seed investment for his early-stage startup. He was also named a Jack Larson Scholar at UC Berkeley's Haas School of Business, receiving a scholarship to pursue entrepreneurship in technology and research.

His technical talents were recognized early, being one of only 11 students nationwide awarded the Snap Research Scholarship for his academic performance, research experience, and ability to solve tough technical challenges. Before college, Andrew was the Salutatorian of his high school class and achieved success in both mathematics competitions (qualifying for AIME four times) and business competitions (placing 2nd at the DECA International Competition).

Andrew is bilingual, with native English proficiency and professional working proficiency in Chinese, adding to his versatile skill set that spans technology, research, and entrepreneurship.

It's important to note that there is another prominent Andrew Tan who is a Filipino billionaire businessman. This Andrew Tan is the chairman of Alliance Global Group, Inc., a major conglomerate with interests in real estate, food and beverage, gaming, and hospitality. Born in Fujian, China, he moved to Hong Kong at age 4 and later to the Philippines as a teenager. He graduated with a degree in accounting from the University of the East in Manila and built his fortune developing large apartment complexes around Manila. His company Megaworld Corporation pioneered the "live-work-play" concept in township development, and he also runs Emperador, the world's largest brandy company by sales volume. As of 2024, his net worth is estimated at $1.5 billion. This is a different individual from the Andrew Tan described in the main profile.

Thomaz has excelled in hackathons, winning first place at HackMIT and second place at PennApps in 2024, while conducting AI research at USC Marshall School of Business focusing on educational applications and LLMs.

Thomaz Felipe Bonato is a passionate engineer, researcher, and lifelong learner from Brazil currently pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Artificial Intelligence for Business at the University of Southern California as a prestigious Trustee Scholar with full tuition. His academic excellence is further evidenced by his National Merit Finalist status.

Thomaz has established himself as an exceptional hackathon competitor, securing first place at HackMIT 2024 with PalmLabs (focused on education) and second place at PennApps 2024 with Cypress MFA (addressing security and privacy challenges). His professional experience spans multiple domains within AI and business. name: arihan v.
short_description: Stanford CS student and accomplished ML researcher specializing in computer vision and LLM applications. With multiple hackathon wins and research experience at UNT's Computer Vision and Intelligent Systems Laboratory, Arihan has developed innovative solutions ranging from cropland optimization using neural networks to sign language interpretation systems.
long_description:
Arihan V. is a promising talent in the field of machine learning and AI, currently pursuing a Computer Science degree at Stanford University (Class of 2028). His technical journey began early, with exceptional academic performance at the Texas Academy of Mathematics and Science and Coppell High School.

As an Undergraduate Researcher at the University of North Texas Computer Vision and Intelligent Systems Laboratory, Arihan has worked on sophisticated projects funded by NASA, USGS, and Physmodo Inc. He also contributed to research at UNT's Functional Glass Materials and Modeling (FGMM) Laboratory as a TAMS student. His research contributions include developing bi-stream convolutional neural networks and deep learning autoencoders to identify cropland levees and optimize farming structures, as well as creating a novel human tracking method using point clouds and depth videos to improve pose estimation accuracy.

Arihan has demonstrated remarkable success in competitive environments, winning multiple hackathons with innovative AI solutions. His projects showcase versatility across different domains:
- Shush: A WhisperV3 model with Flash Attention v2 deployed on Modal via a NextJS app (197 GitHub stars)
- CoWorkr: An AI-powered team knowledge bot
- Koios GPT: A web application combining AI algorithms and LLMs to process research articles and PDFs (1st Place at HackLah! and Code4Good)
- Sign Ease: An app utilizing machine learning to interpret sign language gestures (Winner at MLH's Hack Your Portfolio)
- Transcribi: A web app leveraging OpenAI GPT, Whisper, and Langchain for audio transcription and analysis (1st Place Education Hack at PantherHack)
- SightSense: A wearable device using object detection and text-to-speech to aid visually impaired individuals (1st Place Generative AI at Treasure Hacks)
- ReadSpeak: A comprehensive app for improving reading and pronunciation skills (1st Place at LaunchHacks II)
- PromptGPT: A tool that generates efficient prompts using a custom, finetuned, opensource Dolly v2 model
- Zenset: An expressive writing and journaling app with rewards

His technical expertise spans Python, React, Next.js, TensorFlow, PyTorch, convolutional neural networks, machine learning, statistical analysis, and LLM applications. Arihan has also received recognition for his academic excellence, including the UNT President's List for a perfect 4.0 GPA and the TAMS Summer Scholarship for continued research work.

At Stanford, Arihan is part of the IRIS lab community, which focuses on robotics and machine learning research. He's also been selected as a National Security Innovation Scholar at the Gordian Knot Center for National Security Innovation.

Beyond his technical accomplishments, Arihan has demonstrated business acumen as a DECA Collegiate Business Ethics State Finalist and ICDC Qualifier. His multilingual capabilities include proficiency in English (native), Hindi, Telugu, and Spanish, reflecting his diverse skill set and global perspective.

name: suresh nambi
short_description: Stanford University researcher specializing in hardware optimization for AI systems. Published author with expertise in efficient neural network design, approximate computing, and laser-induced graphitic carbon for electronics. Focused on developing low-power, high-performance hardware solutions for next-generation AI applications.
long_description:
Suresh Nambi is a researcher at Stanford University's Department of Computer Science, focusing on the development and implementation of efficient and effective hardware solutions for AI systems. His research interests span several specialized areas within hardware optimization, including approximate computing, FPGA-based neural network implementations, and novel materials for electronics.

Suresh has made significant contributions to the field through his publications in prestigious journals. His work on "ExPAN(N)D" explored the use of posits (an alternative to floating-point representation) for efficient neural network design in FPGA-based systems, demonstrating his expertise in hardware-optimized AI implementations. He also developed "DeBAM," a decoder-based approximate multiplier designed specifically for low-power applications, showcasing his innovation in energy-efficient computing architectures.

Beyond traditional computing hardware, Suresh has explored novel materials and fabrication techniques. His research on laser-induced graphitic carbon has led to breakthroughs in creating low-resistance conductors, including work on 3D-printed structures. This interdisciplinary approach bridges electronics, materials science, and advanced manufacturing.

Additionally, Suresh has ventured into sustainable energy applications, conducting performance analysis of submerged photovoltaic cells under varying water conditions, demonstrating his versatility and interest in environmentally conscious technologies.

His GitHub repository for the DeBAM project indicates his commitment to open-source contributions and knowledge sharing within the research community. At Stanford, he continues to push the boundaries of hardware design for AI applications, likely focusing on creating more efficient, powerful, and specialized computing solutions for the next generation of artificial intelligence systems.

name: nicole ma
short_description: Nicole Ma is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with a strong background in climate science research. She has published work on global surface temperature projections and has experience at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, where she developed machine learning models for offshore wind resource assessment and forecasting.
long_description:
Nicole Ma is pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Computer Science and Mathematics at Stanford University (2024-2028). Her research interests span climate science, machine learning, and environmental engineering, with a particular focus on applying computational methods to address climate challenges.

Nicole has built an impressive research portfolio at a young age. As a Research Fellow at the Simons Summer Research Program at Stony Brook University, she has been working on novel stochastic process models to simulate the latitude of the North Atlantic Jet Stream. Previously, she interned at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory for over two years, where she developed machine learning models to improve offshore wind resource assessment and forecasting.

Her research has already gained recognition in the scientific community. She published a paper titled "21st Century Global and Regional Surface Temperature Projections" in Earth and Space Science, analyzing observed global surface temperature trends across different latitudinal regions. This work earned her the 2023 CESASC JHJ Prize for Fundamental Science in Physics, an award given to researchers under 26 who have published lead-authored papers in reputable international journals.

Nicole is also passionate about climate justice, serving as President of the Climate Justice Global Alliance. Her commitment to environmental causes is further demonstrated by her numerous awards in science fairs, particularly in environmental engineering and energy conversion/alternate energy categories.

Beyond her environmental work, Nicole has excelled in mathematics and programming competitions. She is a National Merit Scholarship Finalist, American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME) Qualifier, and has won multiple hackathons and programming competitions, including 1st Place at the 2022 igniteCS Programming Expo and 2021 GameGala.

Nicole is bilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Mandarin. She will be participating in Jane Street's WiSE Program in July 2024, further expanding her experience in quantitative fields.

At Stanford, Nicole is registered as an undergraduate student in the Vice Provost for Undergraduate Education department, where she continues to pursue her academic interests while contributing to the university community.

long_description:
Trishala Neeraj is a San Francisco-based Machine Learning Researcher and Engineer at CyberCube, where she applies her expertise to deliver cyber-risk analytics to the global cyber-insurance market. Trishala has made significant contributions to the AI research community, co-authoring several highly influential papers including "BLOOM: A 176B-Parameter Open-Access Multilingual Language Model" (2022), "Multitask Prompted Training Enables Zero-Shot Task Generalization" (2021), and "Beyond the Imitation Game: Quantifying and extrapolating the capabilities of language models" (2022). Her professional experience includes a summer internship at BuzzFeed in 2017, where she worked on a project using K-Means Clustering to tag over 14,000 BuzzFeed quizzes, which she documented in a blog post on the BuzzFeed Tech Blog. short_description: Max Forsey is an AI researcher at the Perception Control and Cognition Lab at Brigham Young University who explores the fundamental nature of intelligence. Max has taken on leadership roles in the AI community, serving as the Vice President of the BYU Artificial Intelligence Association, where he helped organize events and foster a community of AI enthusiasts. He is particularly active in organizing and participating in AI hackathons, recently working with Sameday through the justbuild community to host a 2-hour AI hackathon featuring Cerebras Systems. Beyond his research, Max is passionate about creating practical AI tools. He's also reimplemented Andrej Karpathy's nanoGPT, showing his hands-on approach to understanding AI systems.

Max maintains a personal website where he shares detailed resources for those looking to bridge the gap between using AI APIs and actually training models. name: parsa idehpour
short_description: Parsa Idehpour is a Math and Computer Science student at the University of Pennsylvania pursuing an MSE in Robotics with AI and Machine Learning specialization. He conducts innovative research on neural network "sloppiness" patterns and applies mathematical modeling to evolutionary game theory while working as a Junior Analyst at Wharton Analytics Fellows.
long_description:
Parsa Idehpour is a multidisciplinary researcher and student at the University of Pennsylvania, where he's pursuing both a Bachelor's degree in Math and Computer Science (with minors in Statistics and Engineering Entrepreneurship) and an MSE in Robotics with a specialization in AI and Machine Learning at the prestigious GRASP Lab.

As a Machine Learning Researcher at UPenn Engineering, Parsa is investigating how neural networks avoid overfitting through "sloppiness" - a pattern where models exhibit varying parameter sensitivities that effectively control generalization despite having extensive parameters. This cutting-edge graduate-level project, supervised by Dr. Pratik Chaudhari, aims to develop more streamlined and efficient AI development practices by uncovering common learning patterns across various deep learning models. The research has received support from major grants including the NSF CAREER award and partnerships with industry leaders like Amazon and Intel.

Simultaneously, Parsa conducts research in Mathematical Economics, developing mathematical models to explore evolutionary game theory and switching costs under the supervision of Dr. Akcay and Dr. Plotkin. This independent graduate-level project demonstrates his ability to apply mathematical frameworks to complex economic systems.

In his role as a Junior Analyst at Wharton Analytics Fellows, Parsa builds and trains machine learning models to understand the root causes of worker absenteeism for Dallas Area Rapid Transit (DART), utilizing Python and SQL to analyze datasets and derive actionable insights.

Parsa is also actively involved in the LyRL research lab, where he has implemented PAC-Bayes bounds for neural networks and worked on capacity control in deep learning. His GitHub repository "Parsa-summer-2024" showcases his implementation of methods from academic papers, including work on PAC-Bayes bounds and K-FAC (Kronecker-Factored Approximate Curvature) for neural networks trained on the MNIST dataset.

Additionally, Parsa contributes to MLR@Penn, where he works on predicting biomolecular structures using diffusion models. He has also developed "Augur," a swarm-based prediction tool showcased on Devpost.

Beyond his academic pursuits, Parsa serves as the cultural chair of Penn Persian Club, organizing events that celebrate and support the Persian community. He was selected as a 2025 Sugi and Millie Widjaja Entrepreneurship Fellow at Penn, recognizing his entrepreneurial potential. In his free time, he enjoys playing Persian songs on the piano, voice acting, and rock climbing with Penn's Climbing Club.

Originally from Iran, Parsa brings a unique international perspective to his work, combining technical expertise with cultural awareness and entrepreneurial vision.

name: cooper gamble
short_description: Founding Engineer at Noise Labs with a unique background bridging computer science, physics, and medical AI research. Cooper has published multiple papers on uncertainty quantification and synthetic data in medical imaging, and was recognized as the youngest-ever Fast 5 speaker at the RSNA conference while conducting research at Mayo Clinic.
long_description:
Cooper Gamble is a Founding Engineer at Noise Labs in San Francisco, bringing his technical expertise to this emerging company while pursuing a dual degree in Computer Science and Physics at the University of Southern California (expected graduation 2026). His professional journey showcases a remarkable intersection of software engineering, medical AI research, and quantitative finance.

During his 1.8-year tenure as a Radiology Informatics Intern at Mayo Clinic, Cooper conducted groundbreaking research at the intersection of radiology and artificial intelligence under distinguished mentorship. His work resulted in multiple publications focused on uncertainty quantification for deep learning in medical imaging and the application of synthetic data in medical research. His research contributions earned him recognition as the youngest-ever Fast 5 speaker at the prestigious 2023 RSNA "Leading Through Change" conference, and his work was presented at multiple other professional conferences including the Mayo Clinic AI Summit, International Society for CT, CMIMI, and ASFNR.

Cooper has also demonstrated his technical versatility as a Quantitative Developer at Quant SC, where he developed high-frequency trading platforms implementing state-of-the-art algorithms and researched potential improvements to enhance financial outcomes. His technical skills were further validated through his achievement as a USA Computing Olympiad Gold Division Qualifier.

Beyond his technical accomplishments, Cooper has shown leadership as an Engineering Manager at Develop for Good and through his involvement in humanitarian projects like Run for Ukraine and Run for Lebanon. His academic excellence is evidenced by his selection as a Coca Cola Scholarship Finalist (among 250 from over 91,000 applicants) and his second-place finish at the Harvard Undergraduate Trading Competition.

Cooper's self-description as "Forever curious" aptly captures his multidisciplinary approach to technology and problem-solving, combining rigorous technical skills with innovative thinking across diverse domains including medical AI, quantitative finance, and software engineering.

name: locke cai
short_description: CS & Math student at MIT with exceptional algorithmic expertise as a 2x USACO Finalist and Codeforces Grandmaster. Currently researching reinforcement learning for LLMs and graph neural networks for blockchain anti-money laundering. Incoming ML Research Intern at Together.AI.
long_description:
Locke Cai is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at MIT (2023-2026) with remarkable achievements in competitive programming and mathematics. As a two-time USA Computing Olympiad (USACO) Finalist (2021 & 2022), he was among the top 26 competitors invited to the national training camp, demonstrating mastery of advanced algorithms and data structures. His programming prowess is further evidenced by his Codeforces Grandmaster status, placing him in the top 0.8% of over 100,000 active participants globally.

In mathematics, Locke was selected for the Mathematical Olympiad Program (MOP) Blue Group in 2022, reserved for approximately the top 30 USA Math Olympiad competitors, showcasing his expertise in algebra, probability, geometry, advanced combinatorics, and abstract proof techniques.

His research experience spans multiple areas of machine learning and AI. Currently, he's working as an undergraduate researcher in Professor Pulkit Agrawal's Improbable AI Lab at MIT, focusing on reinforcement learning methods for Large Language Models. He's also made significant contributions to graph neural networks research, co-authoring "Identifying Money Laundering Subgraphs on the Blockchain" which was presented at the International Conference on AI in Finance (ICAIF) 2024. This work introduced RevTrack, a graph-based framework that enables large-scale anti-money laundering analysis with lower cost and higher accuracy.

Previously at Stony Brook University, Locke redesigned and optimized Argus, an end-to-end framework accelerating Convolutional Neural Networks on specialized hardware (FPGAs), with his work expected to be published in ICS 2024. He also has industry experience as a Research Engineering Intern at Anysphere, where he designed and built a production-ready context retrieval system for LLM prompt generation.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Locke is a member of MIT's French House (La Maison Française) where he enjoys philosophical discussions. He's also involved with Traders@MIT, having taught an "Introduction to Trading" class during MIT's Splash program in 2023. In his free time, he enjoys playing piano and hopes to join MIT's Chamber Music Society.

Locke's diverse skill set spans competitive programming, mathematical problem-solving, machine learning research, and practical engineering, positioning him as a rising talent in the fields of computer science and artificial intelligence.

name: kyle cui
short_description: Kyle Cui is the Co-Founder & CEO of CTRL Sheet, a recent graduate from UC Berkeley with degrees in Computer Science (Honors) and Physics. His background spans virtual reality research, AI development, and entrepreneurship, with experience in both academic and industry settings.
long_description:
Kyle Cui is an emerging tech entrepreneur who recently graduated from UC Berkeley with a dual degree in Computer Science (Honors) and Physics. He is currently the Co-Founder and CEO of CTRL Sheet, an AI agent for spreadsheets that helps users build models and gather data from the internet.

Kyle's technical expertise is particularly strong in the intersection of AI and virtual reality. During his time at Berkeley, he conducted significant research in this field, working with the ScenicVR Research Group under Professor Sanjit Seshia where he developed adversarial AI agents in simulated scenarios to boost rapid skill acquisition in VR environments. His research contributions are documented in academic publications, including "A Principled Intelligent Occupational Training of Psychomotor Skills in Virtual Reality" (2023) and "Task Distribution Aware Psychomotor Skill Training with Probabilistic Programs and Bayesian Knowledge Tracing in Virtual Reality" (2024), where he worked alongside researchers like Edward Kim, Zachary Pardos, and Björn Hartmann.

In these research projects, Kyle helped develop innovative approaches to VR training, including the use of Bayesian knowledge tracing (BKT) to predict psychomotor skill mastery, which proved more effective than traditional self-assessment methods. His work demonstrated how probabilistic programming and machine learning techniques could create more effective VR training systems with consistent learning outcomes.

His leadership experience includes serving as Executive Vice President at Extended Reality at Berkeley, where he led internal and external functions for over 50 club members, managing resources, partnerships, and events. Kyle also has teaching experience, having worked as Course Staff for Discrete Math and Probability (CS70) and Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs (CS61A) at UC Berkeley.

Kyle's industry experience includes a Software Engineering internship at Metaphor3D, where he deployed TypeScript applications with Azure for cloud API endpoints, designed user data pipelines in Python, and optimized data processing with Rust. He also gained venture capital experience as an analyst at Steel Perlot.

Multilingual and globally-minded, Kyle is fluent in English and Chinese, with working proficiency in French and Spanish. He also spent time studying abroad at Uppsala University in Sweden. His diverse skill set spans programming languages (including TypeScript, Python, Rust, and C#), AI/ML development, VR/AR technologies, and entrepreneurship, making him a versatile technologist at the forefront of emerging tech.

name: tony wang
short_description: Tony Wang is a Computer Science student at Stanford University specializing in AI, with a diverse portfolio spanning tech, venture capital, and public interest technology. He has research experience at Stanford AI Lab and Harvard Medical School, and has worked with companies like Amazon and Microsoft.
long_description:
Tony Wang is a Computer Science student at Stanford University focusing on Artificial Intelligence. His professional experience spans multiple domains including venture capital, public interest technology, and software engineering.

At Stanford, Tony has taken on leadership roles as the Freshman Council President, where he managed $35,500 for over 1,700 students. He's also involved with TreeHacks as an Alumni Director and serves as the ACM ProCo Director.

Tony's venture capital experience includes positions as a Garage Fellow at Pear VC, a Scout at Soma Capital, and a Founder Fellow at RippleX Fellowship. His interest in public policy is evident through his work as a Fellow at Paragon Policy Fellowship and as a Co-Founder of the Public Interest Technology Lab at Stanford University, where he led the inaugural student govtech fellowship program.

His technical experience includes a software engineering internship at Amazon, contracting work for Swim England and Hypelist, and research at the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) where he worked on deep learning to predict transcription factor binding motifs. He also conducted research at Harvard Medical School under the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and Boston Children's Hospital.

Tony has received several prestigious recognitions, including being a Rise Fellow at Schmidt Futures, where he completed a fully-funded summer intensive in London/Oxford and founded the Rise North America Union. During his high school years at Amador Valley High School, he was the Salutatorian, a Coca-Cola Scholar, a National Merit Scholar, won two gold medals with Kungfu Team USA, and was an ISEF Finalist.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Tony has demonstrated a commitment to community service as the Founder and President of the Alameda County Science and Engineering Fair and as a Teaching Facilitator for Non-Trivial.

name: leo nagel
short_description: Electrical Engineering & Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with expertise in GPU optimization, quantitative finance, and physics. Former Chief Executive at Global Society of Young Physicists and published researcher with a focus on computational efficiency and mathematical modeling.
long_description:
Leo Nagel is an Electrical Engineering & Computer Science student at UC Berkeley who combines technical expertise with leadership experience to drive technological innovation. His academic focus spans GPU kernel optimization, quantitative finance, computing theory, mathematics, and physics.

Currently, Leo is deeply involved in several cutting-edge projects that showcase his technical abilities. He collaborated with Bradley Hsu to develop cuBogo, the fastest bogosort implementation ever run on a single device, optimizing custom CUDA (C++) kernels for the Nvidia H100. He's also working on cuDream, rewriting DreamCoder to leverage GPU optimizations, and cuPrimes, a custom kernel implementing the Fermat test of pseudo-primality using the Schönhage-Strassen algorithm and optimized Fast Fourier Transform with Nvidia H100 tensor cores.

Leo's leadership capabilities are evident through his role as Chief Executive at the Global Society of Young Physicists (2022-2024), where he founded a physics nonprofit that organizes summer programs and publishes a journal. Prior to this, he served as a Curriculum Developer at Mad for Stem, creating interdisciplinary courses spanning economics, computer science, data science, and technology.

His academic achievements include placing first out of 130+ participants in the Berkeley Trading Invitational 2024, demonstrating his aptitude for quantitative finance. Leo has also published research, including a paper on "Derivation of a Function for Velocity for Falling Objects with Non-Negligible Air Resistance," showcasing his mathematical modeling skills.

name: david bai
short_description: David Bai is a Computer Engineering & Computer Science student at USC with diverse research experience in AI alignment, multi-agent robotic planning, and reinforcement learning for legged robots. As a co-founder of Jargon, he's developing language learning tools while also working on innovative projects like brain-controlled drones and GPS-denied navigation systems.
long_description:
David Bai is a Computer Engineering & Computer Science student at the University of Southern California (2023-2027), where he serves as a USC Presidential Scholar. His academic journey is marked by a deep commitment to artificial intelligence research across multiple domains.

Currently, David is a Research Fellow at the Supervised Program for Alignment Research, where he investigates reasoning and AI agents from capabilities and security perspectives. Simultaneously, he works as a Research Assistant at USC Viterbi School of Engineering's GLAMOR Lab through the CURVE Fellowship, focusing on multi-agent robotic planning at the intersection of LLMs and symbolic planners.

David's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his co-founding of Jargon, where he's building a language learning Chrome extension. His technical versatility extends to his work with USC Makers, where he manages projects involving brain-controlled drones using electroencephalography, having previously contributed to an autonomous greenhouse with computer vision.

His professional experience includes a Machine Learning & Computer Vision Internship at Rhoman Aerospace, enabling GPS-denied navigation through VIO and building simulation/SLAM pipelines. David has also served as a Research Assistant at the Dynamic Robotics and Control Laboratory, where he augmented model predictive control for legged robots with reinforcement learning.

In the academic community, David is active with USC's Center for AI in Society's Student Branch (CAIS++), where he contributes to research and projects in artificial intelligence with social impact applications. He is part of the Fall 2024 cohort, demonstrating his commitment to applying AI for societal benefit.

David is also involved with the USC Computational Aerospace Lab, where he works on projects related to BCD (Binary Collision Detection), showcasing his interdisciplinary approach to engineering challenges. This involvement highlights his ability to apply computational methods to aerospace applications.

Prior to USC, David demonstrated academic excellence at Cambridge University, where he compiled comprehensive lecture notes across various mathematical disciplines, indicating his strong foundation in theoretical concepts that underpin his current technical work.

David's commitment to social impact is demonstrated through his volunteer work with the Cheyenne River Youth Project and Friends of Children with Special Needs, where he developed educational courses. His multidisciplinary approach to AI research, combined with his technical skills and social consciousness, positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

name: tristan trouwen
short_description: Tristan Trouwen is a researcher and software engineer affiliated with d-Matrix and Eindhoven University of Technology, with expertise in AI, algorithms, and compiler optimization. His research explores the interaction between automated systems and humans in software development environments, and he has been recognized with the ALSP Scholarship for academic excellence.
long_description:
Tristan Trouwen is a promising researcher at the intersection of software engineering and artificial intelligence, currently affiliated with d-Matrix and Eindhoven University of Technology. His research interests are evidenced by his publication "Between JIRA and GitHub: ASFBot and its Influence on Human Comments in Issue Trackers" (IEEE, 2022), which explores how automated systems interact with and influence human behavior in software development environments.

Tristan's academic excellence has been recognized through the Amandus H. Lundqvist Scholarship Program (ALSP), a merit-based scholarship that includes a tuition waiver and monthly stipend. This prestigious award highlights his standing as a top student in his field.

As an AI Software Architecture Intern at d-Matrix, a series A deep tech startup recognized by Business Insider as one of the 13 most promising AI startups, Tristan worked on optimizing compilers. He applied his algorithmic knowledge from his master's studies to improve existing algorithms, making the platform faster and more power-efficient. This experience allowed him to deepen his understanding of chip architecture and compilers while working in a highly intercultural team environment.

Beyond his technical work, Tristan has demonstrated entrepreneurial initiative through his project "From Scribble To Readable," a book he co-created with fellow student Lourens Touwen to help people write mathematical symbols legibly. The project began when they noticed the difficulty in deciphering their professor's handwriting during an Analysis lecture. They designed practice pages for common mathematical symbols, created promotional videos, and launched a successful Kickstarter campaign to publish the book.

Tristan has also demonstrated leadership capabilities through his role as Board Treasurer for E.S.D.A. Chronos from May 2019 to May 2020. He is also a member of Nova (since November 2022), suggesting continued engagement with professional or academic organizations.

His background combines strong computational methods and software engineering expertise, with a particular interest in how automated systems and human users interact in technical environments - a crucial area for advancing AI systems that can effectively collaborate with human operators. Tristan is fluent in Dutch (native proficiency) and English (full professional proficiency), enabling him to collaborate effectively in international research and development environments.

name: liangze li
short_description: Liangze Li is an AI researcher at Google DeepMind with a background from Carnegie Mellon University's School of Computer Science. His research focuses on natural language processing and AI detection, with publications on distinguishing human from AI-generated content. He has demonstrated leadership through founding multiple organizations at CMU and is multilingual with proficiency in Mandarin, English, Cantonese, and Russian.
long_description:
Liangze Li is an AI researcher currently working at Google DeepMind, one of the world's leading artificial intelligence research labs. He joined DeepMind in 2024 after completing his education at Carnegie Mellon University's School of Computer Science, where he earned his Master's degree in Language Technologies. His academic journey at CMU began in 2017 as an undergraduate student before continuing with graduate studies from 2022 to 2024.

Liangze's research focuses primarily on natural language processing and AI detection systems. He has published several notable papers in this field, including "GPT-Sentinel: Distinguishing Human and ChatGPT Generated Content" and "Token Prediction as Implicit Classification to Identify LLM-Generated Text," both published in 2023. These works have received significant attention in the academic community, with his GPT-Sentinel paper garnering over 70 citations. He has also contributed to research on referential games in NLP with his paper "Listener Model for the PhotoBook Referential Game with CLIPScores as Implicit Reference Chain."

During his time at Carnegie Mellon, Liangze demonstrated exceptional leadership and initiative by founding and presiding over several organizations. He was the Founder and President of the CMU Blackjack Society, as well as the Founder and Lecturer of the Carnegie Mellon University Student College. He also served as President of the Student College Executive Committee and as a Representative in the Graduate Student Assembly.

Before focusing on AI and natural language processing, Liangze had research interests in cryptography, with several publications between 2012-2014 on topics such as pairing computation on Edwards curves and Jacobi quartic curves with high-degree twists. This demonstrates his versatility and depth of knowledge across different areas of computer science.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Liangze has diverse interests in music, having played Alto Saxophone in both the Carnegie Mellon University Kiltie Band and the Pinghe Chamber Orchestra. His intellectual curiosity extends to philosophy as well, as evidenced by his founding of the Pinghe School Philosophy Club and his connection to CMU's Department of Philosophy.

Liangze is impressively multilingual, with native or bilingual proficiency in both Mandarin and English, full professional proficiency in Cantonese, and limited working proficiency in Russian. This linguistic versatility enhances his ability to collaborate in international research settings.

In his own words, Liangze describes himself as being "involved in AI research and startups," indicating his dual interests in both the theoretical advancement of AI and its practical applications in entrepreneurial contexts. His engagement with posts related to machine learning, AI development, and technology startups on LinkedIn further reflects his professional focus and interests in the field of artificial intelligence.

name: dylan b allen
short_description: CEO & Co-Founder of Cheers (YC S24), a frontline experience management platform that transforms in-person business interactions using NFC technology. Dylan has a background in product management and software engineering, with experience at Microsoft Azure and Utah-based B2B tech companies.
long_description:
Dylan B Allen is the CEO and Co-Founder of Cheers, a startup that was accepted into Y Combinator's Summer 2024 batch (YC S24). Founded in 2024 and based in San Francisco (after relocating from Utah), Cheers is building the first Frontline Experience Management platform that transforms in-person service interactions through NFC-enabled employee badges.

Cheers' technology unifies onsite payments, digital tips, real-time reviews, and new-customer referrals in one frictionless flow, helping companies increase their online 5-star ratings, reduce churn, and drive more revenue. The platform is particularly valuable for businesses in home services, field sales, healthcare, and other industries where employees work primarily outside a specific place of business.

Under Dylan's leadership, Cheers has shown impressive early traction, growing from approximately $1,400 MRR in July 2024 to around $4,000 shortly after, with 25 customers including small businesses and one enterprise-level client. The company has processed over 3,000 reviews for customers, with the average client seeing a 5-10x increase in monthly 5-star Google Reviews.

Prior to founding Cheers, Dylan interned at Microsoft Azure and worked at other Utah-based B2B tech companies as a product manager and software engineer. His technical background in frontend engineering has been praised by colleagues, with Adnan Chowdhury describing him as a "well-rounded engineer who also has product management" experience and commending his "can-do attitude and eagerness to learn to solve complex problems."

Dylan graduated from Brigham Young University (BYU) with a degree in computer science and was named to the Marriott School Dean's List in April 2021. During his academic career, he placed in the top 20 of the Student Innovator of the Year competition in Utah, where he pitched his startup idea to a panel of tech investors.

Originally from Dallas, Texas, Dylan is multilingual with professional working proficiency in Spanish, elementary proficiency in Swedish, and native proficiency in English. name: justin ji

long_description:
Justin Ji (also known as Juji) is a junior studying Computer Science at Harvard University (class of 2026). His academic focus has evolved toward AI interpretability research—understanding how AI models work internally to make them safer and more trustworthy for society. During his junior year, he collaborated with the Harvard Kempner Institute on a project investigating how language models adopt "personas" and designing interventions to influence them.

Justin's technical background includes competitive programming and mathematics in high school, where he reached USACO Platinum level and qualified for AIME. At Harvard, he has pursued a rigorous computer science curriculum including graduate-level coursework in Deep Learning (MIT 6.S898), Sensorimotor Learning (MIT 6.8200), and Training Foundation Models (CS 2281R). He has also conducted supervised research (CS 91R) and participated in the Kempner REU summer research program focused on AI interpretability.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Justin is deeply involved in campus life. He founded Book Club @ Harvard and serves on the board of Startups @ Harvard. He is also the Social Chair for Harvard Men's Club Volleyball, Director of Engagement for Harvard Undergraduate Quantitative Traders, and a member of several other organizations including the Harvard AI Safety Student Team, Harvard College Christian Students, and the Taiwanese Cultural Society.

Before Harvard, Justin served as the Whitney High School Middle School Branch and Online Director for Math Matters 4 All, demonstrating his early leadership abilities. His digital creativity was previously showcased through projects like his participation in the Chipotle + David Dobrik TikTok Contest in May 2020.

Justin is an avid reader with diverse literary interests. His favorite books include "The Three-Body Problem" by Cixin Liu, "The Book Thief" by Markus Zusak, and "All the Light We Cannot See" by Anthony Doerr. He maintains an active Goodreads profile and encourages connections through his social media channels.

In his free time, Justin enjoys playing volleyball, reading, and eating at Chipotle. He welcomes connections via LinkedIn or email and is "always happy to meet new people," reflecting his collaborative and community-oriented approach to both his academic and personal pursuits.
