name: alicia li
short_description: MIT CS/AI & Math double major with a strong research background in robot learning and reinforcement learning. First author on a NeurIPS 2024 workshop paper and incoming ML Research intern at Genesis Therapeutics. Founded Watch To Donate, raising over $6,000 for various causes while reaching millions of people.
long_description:
Alicia Li is a talented undergraduate at MIT pursuing a double major in Computer Science/AI (specifically course 6-4: AI and Decision Making) and Mathematics (2023-2027). Her research interests span robot learning, planning, and reinforcement learning, with particular focus on safe RL applications.

As an undergraduate researcher at MIT CSAIL's Learning & Intelligent Systems Group, she works on robot learning and planning, and is the first author on a paper accepted to the NeurIPS 2024 Open-World Agents Workshop titled "Learning to Bridge the Gap: Efficient Novelty Recovery with Planning and Reinforcement Learning." She's also researching safe reinforcement learning for power grid optimization at MIT's Donti Lab, where she was listed as a past member in 2024.

Alicia has an impressive publication record for her career stage, with multiple published papers including work on adversarial attacks against online reinforcement learning agents (as part of MIT PRIMES research project 2022-2023), magic SET squares classification, the Post Correspondence Problem, and coin weighing problems. Her academic excellence is further demonstrated by her coursework in graduate-level subjects including Advanced Algorithms, Inference and Information, and Sensorimotor Learning.

Beyond her academic pursuits, Alicia founded and served as CEO of Watch To Donate from 2020 to 2023, an international student organization that donates revenue from social media videos, mobile apps, and business collaborations. Under her leadership, the organization raised over $6,000 for 27 causes, reached over 6 million people, and developed apps with 9,000+ downloads. She also created a Family Fund to help their online community of 50,000 in need. Additionally, she developed "Play To Donate," an app that leverages ad revenue to enable users to donate to charity by playing games.

Alicia is active in MIT's campus life, participating in MIT Asian Dance Team and Ridonkulous (MIT's competitive hip hop dance team), and was previously on Fixation (MIT's competitive contemporary dance team). She also enjoys figure skating and watching movies with friends in her free time.

She is currently preparing for her upcoming role as an ML Research intern at Genesis Therapeutics, where she'll likely apply her expertise in AI and mathematics to challenges in the therapeutic development space.

name: min xu
short_description: Min Xu is an Associate Professor in the Computational Biology Department at Carnegie Mellon University, with courtesy appointments in the Robotics Institute and Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering. His research focuses on computer vision and machine learning methods for analyzing cellular systems using imaging and omics data.
long_description:
Min Xu (徐旻) is an Associate Professor at the Computational Biology Department within the School of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University. He holds Courtesy Appointments at the Robotics Institute and Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering. He serves as training faculty at the Joint CMU-Pitt Ph.D. Program in Computational Biology and as co-director of the Master of Science in Computational Biology (MSCB) program. He is also a training faculty member at the Master of Science in Computer Vision (MSCV) program at CMU.

Dr. Xu is an investigator at the National Center for Multiscale Modeling of Biological Systems and is affiliated with the Computer Vision Department at the Mohamed bin Zayed University of Artificial Intelligence in UAE. His career has been dedicated to developing computer vision and machine learning methods for analyzing cellular systems using imaging and omics data.

His early work (2000-2009) focused on developing machine learning methods for analyzing functional genomics data. Since 2008, he has shifted his focus to developing computer vision methods for the analysis of Cellular Cryo-Electron Tomography (Cryo-ET) 3D image data. Dr. Xu and his team have designed novel structural pattern mining methods and were the first to demonstrate the feasibility of De Novo extraction of structures and spatial organizations of macromolecular complexes in single cells using Cryo-ET data. His current research focuses on Cryo-ET derived modeling of cellular organization at molecular resolution.

Dr. Xu has published extensively in top peer-reviewed journals and conferences, including PNAS, Structure, ISMB, CVPR, NeurIPS, and MICCAI. His work has been cited over 3,700 times according to Google Scholar. He serves as Principal Investigator on US NIH R01 and NSF awards and received an NSF CAREER award in 2023.

Dr. Xu received his B.E. in Computer Science from Beihang University, M.Sc. from the School of Computing at the National University of Singapore, M.A. in Applied Mathematics from the University of Southern California (USC), and Ph.D. in Computational Biology and Bioinformatics from USC. Before joining CMU, he was a postdoctoral researcher at USC.

In his own words, "Dr. Xu researches for fun, and he enjoys working with highly talented and motivated students." He is open to research collaborations and can be contacted via email at mxu1@cs.cmu.edu.

name: vishal nandakumar
short_description: Vishal Nandakumar is a freshman student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology with research experience in quantum physics, specifically in hydrodynamic quantum field theory analogs. He graduated from Thomas Jefferson High School for Science and Technology, one of the nation's premier STEM-focused high schools.
long_description:
Vishal Nandakumar is currently pursuing his undergraduate studies at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he enrolled in 2024 and is expected to graduate in 2027. Prior to MIT, Vishal attended Thomas Jefferson High School for Science and Technology from 2020 to 2024, which is widely recognized as one of the top STEM-focused high schools in the United States.

During his time at Thomas Jefferson, Vishal demonstrated exceptional aptitude in physics and quantum mechanics. He was involved in a significant research project at the Q Lab focused on "Hydrodynamic Quantum Field Theory Analogs" alongside collaborators Pranav Panicker and Kai Wang. This project explored hydrodynamic quantum field theory, a model of quantum dynamics inspired by Louis de Broglie's double-solution pilot wave theory. Their research involved physically modeling superwalking droplets and pilot wave theory in a silicone oil bath, and extending the two-dimensional form of the hydrodynamic pilot wave to three dimensions by exploring free particles, harmonic oscillators, and other quantum analogs. They also investigated the possible link between non-Markovian dynamics of physical pilot wave systems and nonlocality in quantum systems.

As a developer, Vishal maintains a GitHub presence where he has contributed to projects including "konnecthru" (a JavaScript project) and "Formalin_Predictions_in_Fruits" (a Python project). These repositories demonstrate his programming skills across different languages and domains.

At MIT, Vishal is continuing to build on his strong foundation in STEM fields, particularly in physics and quantum mechanics. His research experience and technical skills position him well for further exploration in quantum physics, computational modeling, and related fields that align with MIT's strengths in these areas.

short_description: Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with extensive game development experience. Co-founder of 646 Studios and former Software Engineer at Microsoft, specializing in user authentication systems and facial recognition technology. First-generation college student from Ethiopia with a passion for technology and community service.
long_description:
Yeabsera Afework is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with a diverse background spanning game development, software engineering, and entrepreneurship. As the co-founder of 646 Studios, Yeabsera has developed three successful video games that amassed over 200,000 community members and achieved 9,000+ concurrent players on release. This entrepreneurial venture led to contracts with major brands like Gen G and Crocs, where Yeabsera's work boosted concurrent players by 5,000+.

At Microsoft, Yeabsera worked as a Software Engineer designing the backend client for the company's first in-house user authentication system, leveraging facial recognition and AI-based liveness verification to enhance security protocols. The role also involved developing secure clients in C# and creating metric dashboards in KustoQL to help on-call engineers identify bugs and outages.

Yeabsera's game development expertise extends to RB Battles LLC, where they designed immersive 3D environments using Blender and Adobe Substance Painter, leading a team of 3D artists to create game elements that attracted over 100,000 concurrent players. Their implementation of efficient workflow strategies accelerated project completion by 20%.

Originally from Ethiopia, Yeabsera moved to Spokane, Washington at the age of 10 and attended All Saints Catholic School before graduating from Gonzaga Preparatory School. At Gonzaga Prep, Yeabsera was recognized as a Salutatorian, placing in the second-highest academic group in the graduating class. He was also a recipient of the Mike Shanks scholarship, which supported his education at Gonzaga Prep.

Yeabsera has been actively involved in community service through Gonzaga Prep's Knights of the Leash program, particularly providing after-school tutoring at his former elementary school, All Saints Catholic School. His AP calculus teacher, Stephen Manfred, described him as an outgoing student with a great personality who "brings joy to the people around him" and "interacts with his peers really well."

As a first-generation university student, Yeabsera is involved with ColorStack, a tech nonprofit that creates academic and professional opportunities for Black and Latinx students entering STEM fields. At Stanford, he benefits from programs designed to support first-generation, low-income (FLI) students in their transition to college life.

Academically, Yeabsera has taken courses in Computer Systems, Design and Analysis of Algorithms, Infrastructure at Scale, Mathematical Foundations of Computer Science, Operating System Principles, Probability for Computer Scientists, and Programming Abstractions and Methodologies at Stanford.

Yeabsera has also participated in selective development programs, including the HeadStart Fellowship for diverse students with outstanding leadership potential, and Jane Street's UNBOXED Scholar program, where they gained experience in quantitative trading through probability, statistics, and game theory challenges.

Currently, Yeabsera is set to join LinkedIn as a Software Engineer for Summer 2025, continuing to build on their impressive technical foundation and entrepreneurial spirit with the long-term goal of establishing a career in the tech industry.

name: ernesto nam
short_description: Ernesto Nam is a Computer Science student at Stanford University specializing in AI, currently building at 11x. With a multilingual background spanning Spanish, English, Korean, and Portuguese, he founded ENGLOBAR PY to address social issues in Latin America and was recognized as a 2020 Straubel Impact Leader. He serves as IFC Vice President of Membership at Stanford and previously gained professional experience at Amazon, Hashdex, and other tech companies during his two gap years.
long_description:
Ernesto Nam is a Computer Science junior at Stanford University with a focus on Artificial Intelligence. Currently, he's building at 11x, an agentic AI company. His professional journey is marked by diverse experiences across technology and entrepreneurship in both Latin America and the United States.

Before starting his university education, Ernesto took two gap years to gain professional experience, working as a Software Engineering Intern at Amazon (Alexa team) and Hashdex, a cryptocurrency investment firm. His entrepreneurial spirit led him to found ENGLOBAR PY, a non-profit organization that seeks to relieve poverty by empowering youth volunteers to engage and contribute to communities in need. Englobar operates in Paraguay and Mexico with over 250 volunteers, offering lessons in math, environmental sciences, and leadership development.

The inspiration for Englobar came during a challenging period in Ernesto's life when his family faced economic difficulties. While volunteering with TECHO (a "Habitat for Humanity" type foundation), he led a housing construction project as the first teenager to lead a build primarily of college students. This experience gave him perspective on helping those less fortunate and became his "true north" for social impact work.

Ernesto's background is impressively international and multilingual, with fluency in Spanish (native), English, Korean, and Portuguese at professional levels. This multicultural perspective has informed his work across borders, including roles at Cloud Humans for business development, content creation at Tract, and consulting for IDB Lab.

At Stanford, Ernesto serves as the IFC Vice President of Membership and has worked on various projects including Blank (a social reading app), AI Deck (a presentation about generative AI for executives in Brazil), Jobi (LinkedIn for blue-collar workers in Latin America), and Edus (cohort-based courses as a new type of university).

His educational journey includes not only Stanford but also participation in Latitud's LF3 program and the Latin American Leadership Academy, where he was an Inaugural Academy Alum and Brazil Leadership Bootcamp participant. Ernesto has also demonstrated exceptional mathematical aptitude, winning multiple medals in National Math Olympiads, including two gold medals and being a nine-time Alto Parana Department Champion.

In 2020, Ernesto was recognized as a Straubel Impact Leader for his work with Englobar, joining a cohort of young leaders developing sustainable solutions to environmental and societal challenges. His diverse background spanning technology, entrepreneurship, education, and social impact positions him uniquely at the intersection of AI innovation and cross-cultural leadership.

name: harshil avlani
short_description: Computer Science and Physics student at MIT with award-winning research in quantum computing. Former Research Intern at MIT's Quanta Group and Arizona State University's Quantum Mechanical Engineering Lab, focusing on quantum error characterization and quantum machine learning applications.
long_description:
Harshil Avlani is a dual-major student in Computer Science and Physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), with an exceptional research background in quantum computing and physics. His academic journey showcases a consistent focus on quantum technologies and computational physics.

Currently, Harshil serves as a Research Intern with the Quanta Group at MIT's Research Laboratory of Electronics, where he applies his interdisciplinary knowledge to cutting-edge quantum research. Prior to this, he gained valuable experience as a Research Intern at Arizona State University's Quantum Mechanical Engineering Lab under Dr. Houlong Zhuang for over a year, developing expertise in quantum mechanical applications and quantum machine learning.

Harshil has achieved remarkable recognition for his research. His project "Analyzing the Effect of Mid-Circuit Measurement (MCM) on Spectator Qubits" earned him first place in the Systems Software category at the International Science Fair and qualified him as a finalist in the prestigious 2024 Regeneron Science Talent Search, where he received a $25,000 academic scholarship. This groundbreaking work identified a previously uncharacterized type of quantum error and revealed significant deficiencies in current quantum simulators.

His research portfolio includes collaborative work on the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) for solving combinatorial optimization problems, documented in his GitHub repository. He has also worked with the Hauser Research Group at the University of Alabama, where he spent 9 months contributing to physics research projects, and gained experience in computer security at Arizona State University's SEFCOM Lab.

In 2022, Harshil participated in the MIT Beaver Works Summer Institute as a Quantum Software Student, further enhancing his skills in quantum computing applications. He has also co-founded the Quantum Beavers hackathon group, which tied for first place in the IBM Quantum Explorers Hackathon.

Harshil has already begun contributing to scientific literature, with a publication in Data in Brief journal on "Dataset on density functional theory investigation of ternary Heusler alloys" in February 2024. More recently, he has been exploring the intersection of quantum computing and transformer models in machine learning, with applications in mitigating misinformation through quantum-enhanced GAN architectures.

Beyond his academic pursuits, Harshil is an accomplished pianist and has a passion for aviation, being able to identify most major aircraft models by sight. His diverse research experiences across multiple institutions highlight his versatility and dedication to advancing the fields of quantum computing and physics through rigorous academic inquiry and practical applications.

name: sheryl chen
short_description: Computer Science student at Stanford University with diverse experience in software engineering, NLP research, and debate coaching. Passionate about applying AI and machine learning to solve real-world problems, particularly in economic policy research and agrivoltaic systems.
long_description:
Sheryl Chen is a Computer Science student at Stanford University who combines technical expertise with interdisciplinary interests. Her professional experience spans multiple domains, showcasing her versatility and drive.

As a Software Engineer at rézme, she's currently applying her technical skills in a startup environment. Simultaneously, she serves as a Debate Coach at Menlo School in Atherton, California, leveraging her national debate success (ranked 2nd nationally in Parliamentary Debate) to mentor students.

Sheryl has demonstrated significant technical capabilities through her work at Fundusol, LLC, where she developed an internal UI for simulating agrivoltaic systems using Django, Celery, Redis, HTML, CSS, SQLite, and Chart.js. Her contributions helped secure contracts with leading international solar development companies, showing her ability to create impactful technical solutions with real business outcomes.

Her research experience is equally impressive. At the Stanford Institute for Economic Policy Research, she worked as an NLP Researcher under Dr. Ashrakat Elshehawy, applying machine learning and natural language processing techniques to extract insights for social sciences research. Her work was significant enough to be presented at the 2024 Global Development Research Symposium.

Sheryl's commitment to community service is evident in her role as a Project Management Mentor at StreetCode Academy, where she guided 17+ adult learners through educational journeys in project management methodologies and approaches.

Her technical foundation was further strengthened during her internship at Auburn University's Data Science and Engineering Laboratory, where she tested and compared state-of-the-art video analysis models within MMAction2, a PyTorch toolbox for action recognition and temporal modeling. She also conducted literature reviews on 3D CNN image classification, demonstrating her ability to engage with cutting-edge research.

Beyond her academic and professional achievements, Sheryl has received notable recognition for her work, including a Perfect Score on the AP Research Exam (top 1.14% globally), being named a 2022 CA National History Day Champion, and receiving Special Congressional Recognition for co-founding Fighting for Heroes, an organization that donated over 40,800 masks to hospitals and vulnerable communities during the pandemic.

As a lifetime Girl Scout member, Sheryl embodies the values of leadership, service, and making a positive impact in her community. Her diverse experiences across software engineering, research, education, and community service position her as a multifaceted technologist with the potential to create meaningful change through her work.

name: arihant choudhary
short_description: Computer Science and Data Science student at UC Berkeley with extensive research experience across AI, cryptography, and computational game theory. Currently working as a Software Intern at Intel and Lead Undergraduate Researcher at UC Berkeley, focusing on multi-agent systems, AI applications, and CS education.
long_description:
Arihant Choudhary is a multifaceted Computer Science, Data Science, and Applied Mathematics student at UC Berkeley with a remarkable research portfolio spanning diverse technical domains. His research journey includes work at Stanford University on multi-agent systems for inference, reasoning, and planning, as well as climate data analysis using CMIP-6 models.

At UC Berkeley, Arihant has made significant contributions across multiple research labs. He serves as a Lead Undergraduate Researcher in two labs under Prof. Dan Garcia - the Computational Game Theory Lab (GamesCrafters) and the CS Education Lab (ACE Lab). In the ACE Lab, he authored papers on dynamic animated feedback for randomized graph problems (accepted at SIGCSE 2024) and co-authored work on personalized reminders for mastery learning (AutoRemind, accepted at SIGCSE 2025). His work in the Computational Game Theory Lab involved developing solvers for games like Quick Cross and Euclid's Game, researching pure draw theory, and creating human-robot interaction systems.

Professionally, Arihant is currently working as a Software Intern at Intel Corporation, implementing cutting-edge research and building products for Intel Foundry. His previous role as a Research Intern at Intel focused on text-to-video research and building Intel's Personal Educator (IPED) using large language models and text-to-speech libraries to support employee training. He also serves as a Dean's Engineering Ambassador at UC Berkeley's College of Engineering, working on programs for high schools and community colleges in the Bay Area.

Arihant's journey to UC Berkeley is particularly inspiring. After being rejected from all colleges in his first application cycle, he took a gap year in 2020 and pursued multiple projects, including a significant climate change research project through Polygence. Working with his mentor Tristan Ballard, a Stanford PhD in earth systems science, Arihant analyzed a petabyte of climate data to study monsoons in Kolkata and assess climate change impacts on agriculture. This experience not only built his technical skills but also helped him secure admission to UC Berkeley on his second attempt.

Arihant's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his founding of Berkeley Social, a platform he developed to help incoming UC Berkeley students connect with peers sharing similar interests. He also co-founded Yindu & Zhongguo Inc, which included the Bangla Machinery Bank, an AgriTech enterprise providing efficient farm machinery to farmers in West Bengal.

His academic pursuits extend beyond UC Berkeley, with coursework at Stanford University in CS224G: Apps with LLMs Inside. Arihant's technical expertise spans AI, machine learning, cryptography, and data science, complemented by his multilingual proficiency in English, Hindi, Bengali, Punjabi, and Marwari.

Through his diverse experiences in research, entrepreneurship, and community service, Arihant demonstrates a commitment to leveraging technology for social impact and educational advancement. Expected to graduate in Spring 2025, he is now interested in pursuing a graduate degree and a career in artificial intelligence/machine learning.

short_description: CS(AI) and Math student at Stanford University with a passion for building innovative AI solutions. Grand Prize Winner at TreeHacks 2024 and co-founder of Intratalent AI. Skilled in multiple programming languages and design tools, with research experience in genomics and computational biology.
long_description:
Jay Khemchandani is a Computer Science (AI) and Mathematics student at Stanford University (2023-2027), who has already made significant strides in the AI and computational biology fields despite being early in his academic journey. As the co-founder of Intratalent AI based in Palo Alto, he's working on optimizing talent through AI solutions.

Jay has demonstrated his technical prowess by winning the Grand Prize at TreeHacks 2024, one of Stanford's premier hackathons. His award-winning project "Baymax" is a vision-powered robotic arm designed to assist individuals with physical impairments using advanced NLP and computer vision. His project portfolio also includes "Mosaic - Wallpapers Inspired by You, Made by AI," which won funding from the 1517 fund at Stanford Startup Society, and "Lucid," a full-stack AI design tool developed by fine-tuning the Flux AI model for commercial projects.

Beyond his entrepreneurial ventures, Jay has been engaged in serious research since 2021. He serves as a student researcher at The Bianchi Lab, working remotely with the University of Miami's Miller School of Medicine, where he gained valuable insights into cognitive disorders and brain lesions. He also participated in The Summer Science Program in 2022, focusing on genomics and computational biology during the intensive three-month research experience.

Jay's technical skills are diverse, including proficiency in C++, Python, Java, MatLab, HTML/CSS/JavaScript, Fusion 360, and Adobe design tools (Photoshop and Illustrator). He's also involved in extracurricular activities at Stanford, including being a member of the JKA Shotokan Karate team.

Jay's academic background is equally impressive, having been the valedictorian at Windermere Preparatory School where he earned his IB Diploma before joining Stanford. His multidisciplinary approach combines technical AI expertise with empathy-driven design, as he consistently emphasizes creating technology that makes a positive impact on society.

With his combination of technical skills, research experience, and entrepreneurial drive, Jay represents the new generation of AI innovators working to apply computational approaches to solve complex real-world problems. He can be contacted at jaykhem@stanford.edu and is based in Palo Alto, California.

name: mikael haji
short_description: A pioneering 19-year-old electrical engineering student at University of Waterloo who leads the Waterloo Hacker Fab building a 10µm open-source DIY chip fabrication facility for under $10K. With extensive experience in neurotech, Mikael has worked with Prophetic on ultrasound technology, contributed to neuromorphic chip design at University of Toronto, and was the youngest intern at Blackrock Neurotech.
long_description:
Mikael Haji is an innovative 19-year-old electrical engineering student at the University of Waterloo and recipient of the prestigious $120K Schulich Leaders Scholarship. He currently leads the Waterloo Hacker Fab team, where he's building a 10µm open-source DIY chip fabrication facility in Waterloo with the ambitious goal of creating a process for under $10K that can produce approximately 1,000 transistors.

His GitHub profile reveals his deep involvement in brain-computer interface (BCI) technology, with multiple repositories focused on EEG applications, including projects for motor imagery systems, P300 spellers, emotion classification, and artifact detection algorithms. He's currently working on burning a GPT-2 layer on silicon and has previously designed a TPU-like systolic array and a neuromorphic chip for neural implants, with a pending IEEE ISSCC paper.

His professional journey showcases remarkable depth in cutting-edge technology fields. At Prophetic, Mikael built an entire transcranial focused ultrasound infrastructure, deploying advanced optimization techniques and accelerating transducer prototyping while creating an $80K hydrophone for under $2K. Prior to this, he worked at the University of Toronto on the digital back-end of a novel neuromorphic chip design, integrating spiking neural networks for advanced neural implants with the Intelligent Sensory Microsystems Lab.

At just 15, Mikael joined WATOLINK as a system integration engineer, helping build a mind-controlled speech interface using SSVEP with GPT-3 integration, which won first place in the Neurotech X student competition. His early accomplishments include being hired as the youngest intern at Blackrock Neurotech, where he engineered custom circuitry enclosures and fabricated high-precision electrode arrays.

Mikael's expertise has earned him recognition beyond academia. He was flown to Dubai for the Global Citizen Forum Conference to discuss his neurotech work and was selected as a Villars Fellow to participate in the inaugural Villars Symposium in Geneva. His entrepreneurial potential was further validated by a $250K matching trust fund from Patrick Poirier at Dragon's Vault to fuel his work in the neurotech space.

His technical innovation began early, with the development of a novel Thermoelectric Generator using fluid technology that earned him the Worley Parsons Engineers of Tomorrow award in 2019. Mikael's unique combination of hardware expertise, neuromorphic computing knowledge, and entrepreneurial drive positions him at the forefront of emerging technologies in chip fabrication and neural interfaces.

One of his notable projects includes developing a highly efficient compression algorithm for Neuralink's N1 implant as part of their compression challenge, which has gained significant attention on GitHub. His diverse portfolio of projects demonstrates his commitment to advancing both hardware and software solutions in the field of neurotechnology and chip design.

name: anirudh kotamraju
short_description: Computer Science student at UC Berkeley with a strong background in machine learning research and software engineering. Currently working on CNNs and autoencoders for Compton telescopes at the Space Sciences Laboratory while previously interning at Amazon and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory.
long_description:
Anirudh Kotamraju is a Computer Science student at UC Berkeley (2022-2026) with diverse experience spanning machine learning research, software engineering, and teaching. Since September 2022, he has been working as a Machine Learning Researcher at UC Berkeley's Space Sciences Laboratory, developing CNNs and autoencoders to approximate the image response of Compton telescopes.

His professional experience includes a Software Development Engineer internship at Amazon (Summer 2024) where he worked on full stack development for the retail division, and a Software Engineer internship at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (Summer 2023) focusing on cyberattack detection for TCP networks in critical U.S. infrastructure. He has also worked at One Convergence on cloud infrastructure.

Anirudh has demonstrated leadership in education as a Teaching Assistant for CS61B: Data Structures at UC Berkeley since Spring 2024, and previously served as a tutor for both CS61B and CS61A courses. His academic journey also includes research in computational astrophysics at UC Santa Cruz (2021) where he built software to optimize the search for very-high-energy gamma ray bursts.

He has an impressive track record in hackathons and competitions, winning the Sustainability Grand Prize at Stanford Treehacks 2024 for developing SkySplat (drones + gaussian splatting for natural disaster response), 1st Place Eluv.io Prize at Calhacks 2022 for Artful (a physical art marketplace preventing forgery through blockchain), and being named the 2024 Bloomberg BPuzzled Challenge UC Berkeley Winner. He also developed Ember, an iOS app that predicts vivid sunsets up to nine days in advance using custom deep learning models.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Anirudh founded a COVID-19 Oxygen Concentrator and Supply Fundraiser for India, showcasing his commitment to humanitarian causes. He's also a member of Launchpad, a UC Berkeley community focused on solving problems with machine learning. His comprehensive skill set spans data structures, machine learning, full-stack development, and computational research, positioning him as a versatile and accomplished technologist with both academic excellence and practical industry experience.

In his free time, Anirudh enjoys landscape photography, listening to film scores, and going on bike rides around the Bay Area.

Devanshi Jain is a Mathematics and Computer Science undergraduate at UC San Diego with a diverse portfolio spanning software engineering, computational research, and mathematical analysis. Her professional journey includes software engineering internships at both Meta and Amazon, where she worked on login core products and cross-border transportation systems respectively.

Beyond her industry experience, Devanshi has demonstrated exceptional research capabilities across multiple domains. At UC San Diego's Center for Energy Research, she improved energy efficiency by 20% through scheduler optimization algorithms. Her work at the Computational Modeling and Flow Physics Lab led to a 12.5% efficiency improvement for NASA's GE90 engine through non-linear optimization techniques, utilizing 200,000 high-performance computing hours for complex CFD simulations.

Devanshi's technical versatility extends to signal processing, where she developed algorithms for acoustic systems and beamforming while working with Triton Robosub. She also built a neurocognitive testing web application for sleep apnea patients at UC San Diego's School of Medicine, contributing to the San Diego Verbal Paired-Associates (SD-VPA) App for testing sleep-dependent memory.

Her leadership experience is equally impressive, serving as President of the Society of Undergraduate Mathematics Students and Technical Chair for IEEE's Student Branch at UC San Diego. She has also participated in multiple advanced mathematics reading groups, studying topics like commutative algebra, functional analysis, and translation surfaces.

Devanshi has published research on turbo-machinery compressor optimization, where her work exceeded NASA's 1980 model efficiency by 12.5%. Her technical skills include Python, JavaScript, React.js, NextJS, AWS, Git, HTML/CSS, Django, and specialized tools like Ansys for computational fluid dynamics.

As an active member of the academic community, she has served as a Teaching Assistant for UCSD Cosmos and participated in various innovation programs including QuForce Innovation Fellow and Blackstone LaunchPad Incubator. Her unique combination of software engineering expertise, mathematical rigor, and research experience positions her as a standout talent in computational problem-solving and optimization.

name: yuwei qin
short_description: A results-driven AI hardware specialist currently at d-Matrix with a strong background in computational electromagnetics and machine learning. Yuwei holds a PhD from Carnegie Mellon University and has extensive research experience in applying deep neural networks to data detection and electromagnetic analysis.
long_description:
Yuwei Qin is a technical professional specializing in AI hardware optimization, currently working at d-Matrix, a company focused on AI compute platforms for inference. With a PhD from Carnegie Mellon University's Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Yuwei has developed expertise at the intersection of hardware engineering and machine learning.

Yuwei's research contributions are particularly notable in the fields of computational electromagnetics, machine learning applications for hardware, and magnetic recording technologies. His publication record includes over 20 papers with more than 150 citations, demonstrating significant impact in his field. His most cited work includes "Machine learning based method of moments (ML-MoM)" (46 citations) and "Deep Neural Network: Data Detection Channel for Hard Disk Drives by Learning" (22 citations).

His research has focused on applying deep neural networks and machine learning to improve data detection in storage systems, particularly for hard disk drives. Notable achievements include developing a CNN-based read channel for hard disk drives that achieved a 30% error rate reduction and 200Mbits/s throughput in 28nm CMOS technology. This work represents a significant advancement in storage system performance through the application of machine learning techniques.

Yuwei has also made contributions to computational electromagnetics, developing machine learning-based approaches for electromagnetic compatibility analysis and parasitic capacitance extractions. His work on electrically tunable polarizers based on graphene-loaded plasmonic cross antennas demonstrates his expertise in applied physics and device modeling.

In the field of heat-assisted magnetic recording (HAMR), Yuwei has conducted research on improving recording performance through micromagnetic modeling and analysis of thermal profiles, contributing to advancements in storage technology.

Throughout his career, Yuwei has collaborated with researchers from institutions including the University of Hong Kong, Western Digital, and Zhejiang University, building a strong professional network in the field of AI hardware and computational electromagnetics.

His technical expertise spans computer engineering, deep learning, storage systems, device modeling, semiconductor device physics, and applied physics, making him a versatile professional at the cutting edge of AI hardware optimization and machine learning applications for hardware systems.

short_description: Computer Science student at University of Maryland and UMD Honors College with a focus on AI-enabled security solutions. Currently working as a Junior Software Engineer at AstraZeneca while developing innovative technologies for school safety through xFoundry@UMD and creating award-winning projects in AI and sustainability.
long_description:
Joshua Vallabhaneni is a Computer Science student at the University of Maryland and part of the UMD Honors College, who balances full-time studies with professional software engineering work. He currently serves as a Junior Software Engineer at AstraZeneca's health-tech subsidiary Evinova, where he works 40 hours per week while maintaining his academic commitments.

Joshua has demonstrated exceptional talent in technology innovation focused on safety and security applications. As a Product Innovation Engineer at xFoundry@UMD, he was selected as one of only 30 students for their inaugural cohort, where he's developing an AI-enabled detection, tracking, and notification system for identifying active shooter events in educational settings in real-time. This venture is backed by significant funding ranging from $250K to $2M.

His experience extends to human-computer interaction, where he worked as an intern at The Center for Applied Technologies for School Security, conducting user testing to enhance the OWL app's usability and applying UX design heuristics to support safer learning environments. Joshua also has experience in 3D animation and interactive media development from his three-year tenure at Siepser Eyecare.

Joshua's technical background includes software engineering internships at PayPal (upcoming), AstraZeneca, and Proxzar, showcasing his versatility across different technology domains. His academic journey includes studies at the University of Maryland, a period at Imperial College London where he focused on Mathematics for Machine Learning, and a high school diploma from Unionville High School in Kennett Square, Pennsylvania.

He has an impressive record of achievements, including first place at the AI for Change Hackathon among 493 participants, first place at JPMorgan Chase's Code For Good Hackathon (selected from 15,000 applicants), and multiple awards at PennApps XXV Hackathon for his work on gesture-driven facial authentication for anti-spoofing and AI deepfake detection. Joshua also received the President's Scholarship from the University of Maryland for his academic and extracurricular excellence.

His portfolio of innovative projects continues to grow, with recent developments including Azalea (an eco-friendly AI model selector that optimizes environmental impact), FireSync (an AI-driven disaster relief coordination system), CypressMFA (gesture-driven facial authentication for anti-spoofing), and SaveAPlate (a predictive modeling system to reduce food waste in dining halls).

Joshua's passion for innovation began at an early age. While still in high school, he invented the "Baby Saver" - a hot car alert device that sends automated alerts to parents and local authorities when the temperature inside a car crosses certain thresholds. This invention was inspired by his concern for child safety when his family was preparing for the birth of his younger brother. The device earned him first place in his grade category and the Safety Award at the 2020 Invention Convention Nationals, hosted by the Henry Ford Museum of American Innovation. His invention received national recognition for its potential to prevent tragic hot car deaths, which claim hundreds of children's lives annually. Joshua's early success with Baby Saver demonstrated his commitment to using technology to solve real-world problems and save lives.

name: rishi sai sadanandan
short_description: Stanford CS (AI) and Math student with a unique blend of venture capital experience, entrepreneurship, and product design. Currently a Pear VC Fellow and VC Analyst at Stanford Social Entrepreneurial Students' Association, while co-founding PocketChangeDigital. Holds three patents for an innovative underwater ear pod system and has a background in finance, data implementation, and classics research.
long_description:
Rishi Sai Sadanandan is a multifaceted Stanford University student pursuing Computer Science with a focus on AI and Mathematics. His professional journey showcases a remarkable blend of venture capital, entrepreneurship, and product innovation.

As a Pear VC Fellow, Rishi works closely with leadership to identify and support high-potential early-stage founders, leading the Green Light program at Stanford to source promising startups for investment. Simultaneously, he serves as a VC Analyst at Stanford Social Entrepreneurial Students' Association, where he's part of a team raising and managing a fund while building a unique investment thesis.

Rishi's entrepreneurial spirit is evident in his role as Co-Founder of PocketChangeDigital, a startup focused on maximizing the use of gift cards. In September 2024, he won $50,000 in the BUC Ventures competition to further develop this venture. He also serves as President of Rem and Company, where he leads a team of strategists rejuvenating small businesses with data-driven solutions. His leadership earned him recognition as "Best President" for the 2024/2025 cycle from the National Chapter.

Perhaps most impressively, Rishi is the Creator and Product Designer of Advanced AquaPods, an underwater ear pod system for which he holds three patents (Utility, Design, and Application). This innovative product enables audio communication and music listening underwater, featuring emergency SOS signals and waterproofing technology. The patents were granted in 2022 and 2024, with the most recent utility patent issued in March 2024.

His diverse experience extends to social impact work with the Stanford Pre-Business Association, where he consulted for an international women's non-profit, working with C-suite executives on brand development and global recognition initiatives. He's also served as a Growth Intern at Cyrano AGI, where he spearheaded Alpha and Beta testing at Stanford and worked with advanced AI algorithms, particularly in NLP and adaptive learning.

Beyond his technical and business pursuits, Rishi is passionate about education and Latin language. He founded "A Dead Language Comes Alive," a non-profit organization that teaches Latin to underserved students while helping them prepare for standardized tests. The program has expanded to multiple schools in the Tampa area, with a special focus on helping Latin American students connect Spanish, English, and Latin to improve their language skills.

Rishi's academic interests are broad, including research in Classics at the University of South Florida, where he explored similarities between origin myths across different cultures. He's also taken courses examining the ethical implications of technology through science fiction, demonstrating his interest in the societal impact of technological advancement.

Originally from Tampa, Florida, and a graduate of Berkeley Preparatory School, Rishi is also an accomplished athlete, having competed in varsity tennis and with the United States Tennis Association, achieving high rankings in Florida. He's committed to education, working as an SAT/ACT Test Preparation Specialist and volunteering as a tutor in various capacities.

Rishi's multidisciplinary approach, combining technical expertise in AI with business acumen and product design, positions him uniquely at the intersection of technology, innovation, and entrepreneurship. His commitment to education and social impact demonstrates his desire to use his skills to make a positive difference in the world.

name: samuel xie
short_description: Samuel Xie is a first-year Electrical Engineering & CS student at Caltech with a strong background in mathematics and computing. He contributes to Caltech's rocketry club by designing PWM control systems for rocket stabilization and conducts geophysics research modeling earthquakes using Python.
long_description:
Samuel Xie is a promising undergraduate student pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Electrical Engineering & Computer Science at the California Institute of Technology (Caltech), class of 2028. He previously attended The Lawrenceville School from 2020 to 2024.

Samuel currently serves as an Engineer for PARSEC, Caltech's Rocketry Club, where he contributes to the MARS/FAR Challenge aiming to launch a rocket to 45,000 ft with stable recovery. His technical contributions include designing and implementing PWM (Pulse Width Modulation) control systems to stabilize rockets during descent and developing control algorithms that integrate hardware/software systems for effective recovery dynamics.

Simultaneously, Samuel works as an Undergraduate Researcher at Caltech's Husker Lab, focusing on geophysics modeling of earthquakes using Python. His research involves analyzing seismic data, simulating earthquake behavior, and utilizing Python-based tools for numerical simulations, signal processing, and visualization of geophysical phenomena.

Samuel has demonstrated exceptional academic achievement, earning recognition as a National Merit Scholar Finalist and receiving the Hubert Alyea Award for excellence in Chemistry from the Princeton Section of the American Chemical Society. His computing skills are evidenced by his advancement to the USACO Gold Division in the USA Computing Olympiad. He has also qualified three times for the American Invitational Mathematics Exam between 2021 and 2023.

Beyond academics, Samuel is a talented athlete who earned the 2023 Scholastic All-American award from USA Swimming, which recognizes students who maintain a GPA of 3.5 or higher while achieving Winter Junior National Qualifying Times. This combination of technical aptitude, research experience, and athletic achievement demonstrates Samuel's well-rounded capabilities and potential for future contributions in engineering and computer science.

name: bill qian
short_description: Yale '26 computer science student in the BS/MS program with a background in competitive programming and mathematics. Currently researching LLMs and code generation, with experience in systems and machine learning. Incoming Software Engineering Intern at Citadel Securities with previous roles at The New York Times and Yale's Gerstein Laboratory. Also serves as Chairman of Cypher Capital, a prominent multi-strategy crypto investment firm.
long_description:
Bill Qian is a computer science student at Yale University (Class of 2026) pursuing a combined BS/MS degree. His technical foundation stems from competitive programming (USACO/ICPC) and mathematics (USAMO/Putnam), which has evolved into expertise in systems, machine learning, and full-stack development.

At Yale's Gerstein Laboratory, Bill has established himself as a researcher in Large Language Models and code generation, publishing multiple papers in natural language processing. His research contributions include work on "ToolLLM: Facilitating Large Language Models to Master 16000+ Real-world APIs" and "BioCoder: A Benchmark for Bioinformatics Code Generation with Contextual Pragmatic Knowledge." He has collaborated with researchers from prominent organizations including Google DeepMind.

Bill's professional experience spans diverse environments. He's secured an upcoming Software Engineering Internship at Citadel Securities (New York) focusing on high-performance C++. Previously, he worked at The New York Times on their Research and Development team, exploring ethical applications of AI and LLMs in journalism. At DeepMedia, he designed and optimized algorithms for heterogeneous data analysis, creating a machine translation model with 10% better performance than competitors using Transformers, Python, PyTorch, and Rust.

His technical versatility extends to infrastructure development, having designed distributed computing systems using AWS, Azure, and on-premise hardware with Docker, Kubernetes, and SQS. At Thomas Ho Company, he applied neural networks to assess mortgage loan pricing models and implemented ETL pipelines that improved data processing efficiency by 30%.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Bill is actively involved in campus life as a Project Manager at the Student Technology Collaborative, where he manages knowledge base development and provides technical support across multiple operating systems. He balances his technical interests with creative outlets, singing with the Yale Glee Club and making short films.

In parallel to his academic career, Bill serves as the Chairman of Cypher Capital, a leading multi-strategy crypto investment firm based in the UAE. Before joining Cypher Capital in 2022, he was the Global Head of Fundraising, Binance Labs, and M&A for Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency platform. Prior to that, he was Head of Investment for Fintech and Technology at JD.com, a leading Asian internet platform generating over $400 billion in annual gross merchandise volume.

Throughout his career in the blockchain and cryptocurrency sectors, Bill has deployed and managed over $30 billion in investments across AI, cryptocurrency, and fintech. He has successfully invested in prominent blockchain projects including Solana, Mysten Labs (Sui), Ton, Sei, and Bouncebit. He also serves on the board of the TON Foundation and is Managing Director and Chief Investment Officer of Phoenix Group (ADX: PHX), the first cryptocurrency company to go public in the Middle East.

Bill holds a Bachelor of Engineering from Shanghai Jiao Tong University, an MSc in Finance from Nanyang Technological University, and an MBA from the University of Toronto. He is also an executive committee member of the Hillhouse Value Investing Institution.

His unique combination of deep technical expertise in computer science, extensive experience in blockchain investment, and leadership in the cryptocurrency industry positions him as a multifaceted contributor across both academic and professional domains.

short_description: Vatsal Baherwani is a computer science undergraduate at the University of Maryland focused on AI research, particularly in making AI more accessible, interpretable, and trustworthy. He is a research fellow at the Center for Human-Compatible AI, working to ensure AI systems align with human values and safety.
long_description:
Vatsal Baherwani is an undergraduate computer science student at the University of Maryland, set to graduate in 2025. His research interests center on making artificial intelligence more accessible, interpretable, and trustworthy. As a research fellow at the Center for Human-Compatible AI, he works on ensuring AI systems remain aligned with human values and safety considerations.

Vatsal's research portfolio includes several notable projects. He has investigated how video diffusion models encode motion information in early timesteps of the diffusion process, leading to a method for targeted video motion customization. He co-authored a paper on improving routing for sparsely-gated mixture-of-experts models that was accepted at NeurIPS 2024. Additionally, his work on racial and gender stereotypes encoded in CLIP representations was published at ICLR 2024 as a Tiny Paper.

Beyond his research, Vatsal is an active writer who shares his knowledge about AI concepts through his Medium blog. His articles include explanations of gradient descent in AI learning, perspectives on AI-proofing education, and philosophical reflections on finding passion. This demonstrates his commitment to making complex AI concepts accessible to broader audiences.

Vatsal has a strong technical foundation, having completed certifications in deep learning through Kaggle, machine learning through Stanford Online, and financial market concepts through Bloomberg. His GitHub profile showcases various projects including Shore-Defense, StudySession, PlayboardWeb, and Plannet - a platform for friends to collaboratively plan hangouts.

As an emerging researcher in the field of human-compatible artificial intelligence, Vatsal combines technical expertise with a focus on the ethical implications of AI development. His interdisciplinary approach and commitment to AI safety position him as a thoughtful contributor to the field of AI research.

name: advait iyer
short_description: Computer Engineer with expertise in computer systems, specializing in hardware and software engineering. Currently a Software Engineer at Tesla with research experience in GPU-accelerated data analytics, and a published paper on overcoming memory capacity limitations in large-scale data analytics.
long_description:
Advait Iyer is a Computer Engineer with a strong focus on computer systems and hardware design. He graduated from the University of Michigan with a Bachelor of Science in Engineering in 2024. Advait has built an impressive career trajectory, currently working as a Software Engineer at Tesla while also contributing to academic research.

His technical expertise spans C/C++, Verilog/SystemVerilog, and Python, with a particular interest in computer architecture and systems design. At Tesla, Advait has worked on several significant projects including the revamped on-screen PRND gear slider for the 2024 Model 3 released in Europe and China, navigation and controls features, and a performance monitoring library for the infotainment system. He also contributed to the development of the new weather feature for the 2024 summer release.

As a Hardware Engineer at Aethero, Advait helped build space-rated edge AI computers, demonstrating his versatility across both software and hardware domains. His academic contributions include serving as an Instructional Assistant for Advanced Computer Architecture (EECS 470) and Digital Logic Design (EECS 270) at the University of Michigan. In the Computer Architecture course, he taught lab sections on hardware design using SystemVerilog and helped students design synthesizable out-of-order RISC-V processors. For the Logic Design course, he co-created and maintained the course's RTL DV platform deployed on autograder.io using Docker, which was used by approximately 300 computer engineering students per semester.

Advait's research as a Research Assistant in the CE Lab at the University of Michigan focused on GPU acceleration for heterogeneous LLM/DB workloads, resulting in a publication titled "Vortex: Overcoming Memory Capacity Limitations in GPU-Accelerated Large-Scale Data Analytics" accepted to VLDB 2025.

His impressive project portfolio includes a 94 MHz RISC-V CPU with P6 style renaming and N-way superscalar design, a foldable cloth piano, formal verification of a fault-tolerant cache coherence protocol, and various FPGA design projects. He has also worked on robotic planning and controls projects and numerous C/C++ projects including a RISC-V assembler, simulator, and linker.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Advait has explored entrepreneurship and venture capital as a Venture Partner at Contrary for over three years. He has also worked at Marathon Digital Holdings (MARA) as an Engineering Intern optimizing merged mining protocols, and contributed to Zepto (formerly KiranaKart, YC W21) in operations, growth, and engineering roles.

Advait has also written about the intersection of data science and spirituality, exploring how machine learning concepts can provide insights into human behavior and decision-making. His writing demonstrates his ability to connect technical concepts with broader philosophical ideas.

His academic achievements include being a runner-up in the APS History of Physics Essay Contest and winning the Gold Award in the Queen's Commonwealth Essay Competition. He is multilingual, with proficiency in English, French, Hindi, and Tamil, reflecting his global perspective and communication skills.

name: zeyneb nahide kaya
short_description: Zeyneb Nahide Kaya is a CS student at Stanford University and accomplished NLP researcher focusing on data efficiency and interpretability in AI algorithms. As a Regeneron Science Talent Search Top 5 Winner and Coca-Cola Scholar, she has published multiple papers on low-resource languages, multilingual data augmentation, and language model understanding of morphology. She is also the founder of Romeyka Everlasting, a nonprofit dedicated to preserving the endangered Greek dialect.
long_description:
Zeyneb Nahide Kaya is a Computer Science student at Stanford University with a distinguished research background in Natural Language Processing. Her research interests focus on understanding and advancing NLP algorithms, particularly in areas of data efficiency and interpretability to enhance the robust reasoning capabilities of algorithms beyond shallow pattern memorization.

Zeyneb has achieved remarkable recognition in the scientific community at a young age. She placed 5th in the prestigious Regeneron Science Talent Search, winning a $90,000 award, and was selected as a Coca-Cola Scholar from over 103,000 applicants. Her academic excellence is further highlighted by being named a NCWIT Aspirations in Computing National Winner in 2023 and a U.S. Presidential Scholar Semifinalist in 2024.

Her research portfolio is impressive and diverse, with publications spanning multiple areas of computational linguistics. Her work includes studies on "Full Scope Word Embedding Variability for Low-Resource Languages" (IEEE MIT URTC), "Measuring the Impact of Data Augmentation Methods for Extremely Low-Resource NMT" (LoResMT @ EACL, cited 5 times), and "MADLIBS: A Novel Multilingual Data Augmentation Algorithm for Low-Resource Neural Machine Translation." She has also explored the intersection of linguistics and computer science in works like "The Pervasiveness of Language Contact: Evidence from Negative Existentials in Romeyka/Turkish Code-Switching" (Proceedings of the Linguistic Society of America) and "Language Models' Understanding of Agglutinative Morphology." Her recent work includes "Decoding Large-Language Models: A Systematic Overview of Socio-Technical Impacts, Constraints, and Emerging Questions" (arXiv, 2024).

Zeyneb is the founder and president of Romeyka Everlasting, a nonprofit organization dedicated to preserving Romeyka, an endangered Greek dialect spoken in regions of Turkey near the Black Sea. Through this initiative, she works towards developing computational methods for the documentation and analysis of the dialect, helping to preserve its linguistic heritage and cultural traditions.

Beyond her research, Zeyneb serves as an Ambassador for Women in Data Science (WiDS) Worldwide and has co-authored a book titled "Breaking Barriers: Celebrating Women and Diversity in Data Science" which became an Amazon #1 New Release in STEM Education. She has also authored "Everlasting Connection: Language, Time, Society, and Technology."

Her academic achievements include extensive coursework in NLP, including Natural Language Processing with Deep Learning, AI & Language, Programming Abstractions, Computer Organization & Systems, Probability for Computer Scientists, and Mathematical Foundations of Computing at Stanford. Prior to Stanford, she maintained a perfect 4.0 GPA at Saratoga High School (2020-2024) where she served as AI Club Co-President and Linguistics Club Founder & President.

Zeyneb's technical expertise is complemented by her linguistic abilities, being fluent in English and Turkish with working proficiency in Chinese. Her achievements in linguistics competitions include 10th place globally (1st in USA) in the Online Linguistics Olympiad and qualifying for the Invitational Round of the North American Computational Linguistics Olympiad.

At hackathons, she continues to excel, winning the Scrapybara Sponsored Award at TreeHacks 2025. Her combination of technical depth, research acumen, and linguistic knowledge positions her as a rising star in the field of AI and computational linguistics.

name: evan wang
short_description: Evan Wang is a researcher at Scale AI and Caltech graduate specializing in AI, with notable contributions to natural language processing and federated learning. His research has been featured at prestigious conferences including ICLR and NeurIPS, and he has demonstrated exceptional skills in competitive programming and data science competitions.
long_description:
Evan Wang is a talented AI researcher currently working at Scale AI after studying at Caltech. His research focuses on advanced AI techniques, particularly in natural language processing and distributed learning systems.

His publication record demonstrates his expertise in multiple AI domains. His recent work "Planning In Natural Language Improves LLM Search For Code Generation" was accepted as a Spotlight paper at ICLR 2025 and featured at the System 2 Reasoning workshop at NeurIPS 2024, showing his contributions to improving how language models generate code. He has also published significant work on federated learning with "SWIFT: Rapid Decentralized Federated Learning via Wait-Free Model Communication" (ICLR 2023 and NeurIPS FL Workshop 2022), and graph neural networks with "Sketch-GNN: Scalable Graph Neural Networks with Sublinear Training Complexity" (NeurIPS 2022).

Evan's academic journey includes undergraduate studies at the University of Maryland, College Park (2021-2022) before transferring to the California Institute of Technology (2022-2025). During his time at Caltech, he was involved in campus activities, as evidenced by his candidacy in the ASCIT Winter Elections where another student named Evan Portnoi was also running for IHC Chair.

Evan has demonstrated exceptional analytical and problem-solving abilities through his competitive achievements. He won 2nd place at the Citadel Global Data Open and 1st place at the Citadel West Coast Data Open, showcasing his data science skills. His programming prowess is evident from qualifying for the ICPC North America Championship representing Caltech and reaching the USA Computing Olympiad Platinum Division (top 300 high school students in the US). He also placed in the top 500 in the prestigious Putnam mathematics competition.

In addition to his research work, Evan gained practical industry experience as a Research Intern at Scale AI in 2024 before taking on a full-time role there. His profile on OpenReview confirms his academic affiliations and research interests in the AI community.

He is multilingual, with native proficiency in both English and Chinese, and limited working proficiency in Spanish, which enhances his ability to collaborate in diverse international research environments.

name: sathvik redrouthu
short_description: Sathvik Redrouthu is a tech innovator and entrepreneur who founded Procyon Photonics while in high school to develop photonic computing technology. Currently at Etched, he previously worked on chip design tooling through his startup Instachip. His research focuses on optical computing, photonic integrated circuits, and tensor algebra implementations for next-generation computing architectures.
long_description:
Sathvik Redrouthu is a forward-thinking technologist, entrepreneur, and researcher at the intersection of optoelectronics, hardware acceleration, and advanced computing architectures. Currently working at Etched and previously associated with Y Combinator, Sathvik has established himself as an innovator in specialized computing hardware despite his young age.

As the founder, CEO, and CTO of Procyon Photonics, Sathvik became the world's youngest CEO in the photonic and optical computing sector. Founded in 2021 while he was still in high school at Thomas Jefferson High School for Science and Technology, Procyon develops revolutionary photon-based computing technology that aims to overcome the limitations of traditional electronic computing. The company's optical chips are designed to be significantly more energy-efficient than conventional processors, with prototypes reportedly 55,000 times more energy-efficient than the Intel i9 and over 100 times more efficient than Nvidia's A100 or Google's TPU. Procyon secured venture funding from Peter Thiel's 1517 Fund and has attracted interest from tech leaders like Sam Altman of OpenAI.

Before joining Etched, Sathvik founded Instachip, an EDA (Electronic Design Automation) startup focused on chip design tooling, and participated in Y Combinator. He is also conducting Formal Verification research with Dr. Mark Santolucito at Columbia University.

His research portfolio includes significant contributions to optical computing, with publications focused on optoelectronic hardware accelerators for tensor arithmetic. His work on "Tachyon," a programmable optoelectronic hardware accelerator, demonstrates his expertise in designing systems for ultrafast tensor operations. His team at Procyon was the first to run tensor algebra on an optical chip. Additionally, he has published on tensor algebra implementations for optoelectronic microchips and the use of interferometer-based photonic integrated circuits for rapid unitary transformations.

Sathvik's technical focus is on leveraging optical technologies to overcome limitations in traditional electronic computing, particularly for matrix multiplication and tensor operations critical for AI and machine learning workloads. His work on implementing unitary matrix transformations through Mach-Zehnder interferometers shows a deep understanding of how to harness photonic principles for computational advantage.

Beyond his professional work, Sathvik has developed numerous projects including AI chess engines, regex interpreters using Brzozowski derivatives, tensor algebra compilers with sparse tensor storage systems, and various AI applications. He is also skilled in hardware development, having created electric guitars and EMP generators from scratch.

Sathvik graduated high school in June 2024 but decided not to attend university, instead pursuing entrepreneurship and practical research. His vision is to someday "power the world with light" through photon-based computing, which he believes represents the next revolution in computing technology.

name: alex fan
short_description: Alex Fan is a talented undergraduate at MIT studying Mathematics and Computer Science with a focus on AI research. A USACO Finalist in 2021 and 2022, he's currently working as a Research Engineer at Pika, tackling challenges in generative video and image models.
long_description:
Alex Fan is a promising talent in the AI field, currently pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Mathematics and Computer Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (2023-2026). His academic journey includes rigorous coursework in graduate-level Machine Learning, Advanced Algorithms, Advances in Computer Vision, and Computational Cognitive Science, demonstrating his commitment to mastering both the theoretical foundations and cutting-edge applications of AI.

Alex's technical prowess was evident early on, as he was a USACO (USA Computing Olympiad) Finalist in both 2021 and 2022 during his time at Lexington High School. This competitive programming background has provided him with strong algorithmic thinking skills that complement his AI research interests.

Currently, Alex is working as a Research Engineer at Pika, where he focuses on solving engineering and research challenges related to generative video/image models and data curation. This practical experience in the rapidly evolving field of generative AI is giving him hands-on exposure to state-of-the-art techniques and real-world applications.

During his time at MIT, Alex has been involved in various research projects. In 2022, he participated in the PRIMES program where he collaborated on research leveraging statistical distributions for RNA sequencing across time, working with Prof. Gil Alterovitz. This experience demonstrates his interest in applying computational methods to biological data.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Alex is an active member of the MIT community. He lives in La Maison Française (MIT French House) where he embraces French culture and language. He's also involved in the performing arts, having performed in the MIT Musical Theatre Guild's Cabaret Night in Fall 2023 and cast as John Hinckley Jr. in their production of "Assassins" for Fall 2024.

Alex has diverse personal interests including cooking, baking, fermentation, Broadway musicals, and playing piano. He describes himself as a francophile who dreams of returning to Parisian cafes. In his spare time, he enjoys working on programming projects and writing blog posts, showcasing his passion for both technical and creative pursuits.

His engagement with the AI community is evident through his LinkedIn activity, where he follows developments in AI research, particularly in generative models and applications in various domains. Alex represents the next generation of AI researchers and engineers who are combining strong mathematical foundations with practical implementation skills to push the boundaries of what's possible in artificial intelligence.

name: vijay kumaravelrajan
short_description: Vijay is a junior at USC studying Math and Computer Science, where he serves as a Project Lead at USC's Center for AI in Society. His research spans inference-time compute scaling for LLM language translation, robotic manipulation, and 6G wireless technology. As a co-founder of Jargon, he's building an LLM-powered language learning Chrome extension.
long_description:
Vijay Kumaravelrajan is a junior at the University of Southern California pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Mathematics and Computer Science. As a Trustee Scholar and Viterbi Fellow, he has established himself as a multifaceted researcher and entrepreneur in the AI space.

At USC's Center for AI in Society (CAIS++), Vijay currently leads a team of five researchers focused on inference-time compute scaling for LLM language translation, where they're achieving superior pass@k performance under tighter inference budgets compared to larger models. His work involves implementing and analyzing various inference-time scaling strategies including best-of-n approaches, tree search with PRMs, and Chain of Thought with reinforcement learning. Previously at CAIS++, he conducted research in robotic manipulation through collaboration with USC's SLURM lab, implementing environment simulations using MuJoCo and ManiSkill with Gymnasium for reinforcement learning training. He has also served as a Curriculum Lead, mentoring underclassmen through practical ML projects and teaching comprehensive curriculum covering neural networks, classical ML, NLP, computer vision, transformers, and generative modeling.

Beyond his academic research, Vijay co-founded Jargon, a startup developing a Chrome extension that transforms everyday browsing into language learning opportunities powered by large language models. His entrepreneurial venture demonstrates his ability to apply AI technologies to practical educational tools.

Since August 2022, Vijay has been a Directed Researcher at USC's WiDES Lab, where he collaborates with PhD leads and a team of graduate and undergraduate researchers. His work includes designing and optimizing ray tracers for 6G wireless installations and using convolutional neural networks alongside traditional algorithms to detect edges in point cloud data. He implements C++ libraries in Python and MATLAB, showcasing his versatility across programming languages.

Earlier in his academic career, Vijay worked as a Research Assistant at Scholar Launch, conducting research on open star clusters under the guidance of a professor from UT Austin. He created generalizable algorithms for determining the age of any star cluster of interest using Python.

Vijay has demonstrated his programming skills in competitive settings, participating in the Fall 2024 USC Programming Contest where he successfully solved the "5-Mile Hike" problem using Python. He also contributed to the "Gen-AI for Multi-Agent Deformable Object Manipulation" project at CAIS++, working alongside other researchers to advance robotic manipulation of deformable objects like bread and clothing. This project integrated various robotic platforms including ALOHA and Baxter into the MuJoCo simulation environment using Robosuite, setting up bimanual configurations to explore different arm controllers.

Outside of his AI and computer science pursuits, Vijay is involved with USC's Rocket Propulsion Lab as a General Member focusing on simulations. He achieved the rank of Eagle Scout with Boy Scout Troop 1776 and graduated with an IB Diploma, demonstrating his well-rounded capabilities and leadership potential.

Vijay's personal website (jaykr.dev) features his projects and writing, reflecting his passion for discovering and building new technologies at the intersection of mathematics, computer science, and artificial intelligence.

name: ricardo skewes zorrilla
short_description: A multilingual Physics and Computer Science student at Harvard with exceptional achievements in quantum computing and international physics competitions. Ricardo combines technical expertise with diplomatic skills, having led international relations organizations and conducted research spanning solid-state physics, ESG consulting, and quantum algorithm development across multiple languages.
long_description:
Ricardo Skewes Zorrilla is a Physics and Computer Science student at Harvard University with a remarkable blend of technical expertise and international perspective. His academic journey is distinguished by significant achievements in quantum computing, where he serves as Vice President of the Harvard Undergraduate Quantum Computing Association (HUQCA) and won 2nd place at MIT's Quantum Computing Hackathon 2024, developing theoretical error bounds for quantum algorithms.

Ricardo's technical prowess extends beyond quantum computing to solid-state physics research, where he worked with 2D transition metal dichalcogenides and Van der Waals heterostructures under Professor Hongkun Park. His computational skills have been recognized through multiple hackathon victories, including Microsoft's Student Hackathon 2021 and CdCMx 2020, where he developed mathematical models for COVID-19 comorbidity analysis.

In the quantum computing field, Ricardo has demonstrated exceptional talent, helping to grow HUQCA to over 300 members. At the MIT Interdisciplinary Quantum Hackathon (iQuHACK), his team created an "experimental harness" that allowed them to run quantum simulations at scale and efficiently collect data, earning them second place. As Ricardo noted, "It's one thing to learn something in a classroom, and another to try to code one and see if it runs. That's different, and I think it adds an extra layer to fully mastering the concepts."

long_description:
Kevin Taylor is a high school student at Monte Vista High School (Class of '25) who has already built an impressive portfolio in AI, developer relations, and education.
