Kevin's technical experience is diverse and substantial for his age. He co-authored a research paper on multimodal neural networks that was accepted to the Intelligent Systems Conference. At SNP Communications, he developed AI-powered tools including a live AI communications coach with realistic voice and an AI-powered internal sales proposal generator. He also created an accessibility platform called NodNet.org to aid amputees with computer use, utilizing head-tracking technologies for cursor movement.

Kevin has extensive teaching experience, working as a math tutor for subjects ranging from Algebra to Calculus II, and as a self-employed programming instructor teaching students aged 6-16. He previously interned at theCoderSchool, teaching programming skills in various languages including Lua, Python, Java, HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and C#. He has also volunteered as an instructor for EngageSTEM, teaching Java to underserved middle school students.

His community involvement is equally impressive. Kevin serves as an Advisory Board Member for the Town of Danville (the youngest member ever admitted), helping with fundraising efforts for the library and working on programs for teenagers. He has volunteered over 150 hours through Lion's Heart - Teen Volunteers and Leaders, teaching programming to students in the Bay Area. He's also an active member of Boy's Team Charity, serving various organizations including the Nephrotic Syndrome Foundation and the Monument Crisis Center.

Kevin's educational background includes participation in specialized programs like COSMOS at UC Davis, where he programmed simulations in Python and studied Biophysics and Robotics, and Inspirit AI, where he worked with PhDs to develop a computer vision model for driverless cars.

His combination of technical skills, teaching experience, and community service demonstrates a well-rounded individual with a passion for technology and education, particularly in making AI and programming accessible to others.

Note: This Kevin Taylor should not be confused with other individuals with the same name, including a restaurateur in Denver who owns the Kevin Taylor Restaurant Group, a radio show host on "The Kevin and Taylor Show," or the Kevin Taylor from Philadelphia who tragically died in a hit-and-run accident in October 2024.

name: eduardo pontes reis
short_description: Eduardo Pontes Reis is a physician-researcher specializing in radiology and AI applications in healthcare. Currently affiliated with Stanford University and Hospital Israelita Albert Einstein, he focuses on developing AI tools for medical imaging and clinical documentation. His research has been cited over 1,200 times, with significant contributions to medical text summarization, chest X-ray interpretation, and multimodal medical AI systems.
long_description:
Eduardo Pontes Reis is a physician-researcher at the intersection of medicine and artificial intelligence, currently serving as a Visiting Scholar at Stanford University's Center for Artificial Intelligence in Medicine & Imaging (AIMI) and as a researcher at Hospital Israelita Albert Einstein in Brazil.

His educational background includes an MD from State of Sao Paulo University (UNESP) in 2013, followed by a Radiology Residency at UNICAMP in 2017, and Neuroradiology specialization at Hospital Israelita Albert Einstein in 2018. This clinical foundation has informed his research focus on applying AI to healthcare challenges.

Eduardo's research has gained significant recognition in the field of medical AI. According to Google Scholar, his work has been cited over 1,200 times, with an h-index of 13. His research contributions span several important areas:

1. Medical Text Summarization: He co-authored a groundbreaking study published in Nature Medicine demonstrating that adapted large language models can outperform medical experts in clinical text summarization, potentially reducing documentation burden for clinicians.

2. Medical Imaging AI: He has contributed to multiple projects involving AI applications in radiology, including the development of BRAX (Brazilian labeled chest X-ray dataset), and participated in the creation of ChexAgent, a foundation model for chest X-ray interpretation.

3. Multimodal Medical AI: His work includes contributions to Med-Flamingo (a multimodal medical few-shot learner) and Merlin (a vision-language foundation model for 3D computed tomography).

4. Clinical Applications: Eduardo's research focuses on practical applications that can improve healthcare delivery, including automated contrast phase detection in abdominal CT and AI tools for radiology report generation.

At Stanford, Eduardo is part of the Machine Intelligence for Medical Imaging (MIMI) research group led by Dr. Akshay Chaudhari, where his research focuses on developing AI tools to improve healthcare, particularly in radiology and medical records. His specific interests include methods that use pairs of images and reports to teach radiology to computers, and applying large language models to reduce documentation burden for medical professionals.

Eduardo is an advocate for open data in healthcare when safe and feasible, contributing to the development of open-source datasets and tools. His professional affiliations include membership in the Sociedade Paulista de Radiologia (São Paulo Radiology Society), Colégio Brasileiro de Radiologia (Brazilian College of Radiology), and CREMESP (Regional Council of Medicine of the State of São Paulo).

Beyond his professional pursuits, Eduardo enjoys tennis, music (particularly playing the piano), and hiking. He is fluent in Portuguese (native) and English (professional proficiency), enabling him to engage with international research and collaboration opportunities in his field.

name: alan wu
short_description: Alan Wu is a Caltech student and accomplished competitive programmer with a passion for AI research, particularly in large language models and autonomous driving. He has won multiple prestigious competitions including the Citadel Data Open Global Championship and has published research on LLM linearization and 3D semantic segmentation.
long_description:
Alan Wu is a junior studying Computer Science at Caltech, having transferred from Harvey Mudd College where he studied Computer Science and Mathematics from 2021 to 2023. His academic interests span across programming, mathematics, and artificial intelligence, with a particular focus on large language models and computer vision for autonomous driving.

Alan's research contributions include work on "LoLCATs: On Low-Rank Linearizing of Large Language Models" (ICLR 2025), which proposes a novel two-step approach to linearize LLMs while maintaining model quality, and "DenseFuseNet: Improve 3D Semantic Segmentation in the Context of Autonomous Driving with Dense Correspondence" (IEEE), which explores multi-modal perception systems for autonomous vehicles. His high school research on 3D semantic segmentation earned him the Bronze Prize (3rd place) in the prestigious S.-T Yau High School Science Award, competing against over 1000 global research projects.

Currently, Alan works with RSRG@Caltech on distributional robust reinforcement learning and uncertainty quantification. He has also conducted research on theoretical ML with Prof. George Montanez at the AMISTAD Lab, resulting in a paper published in ICAART 2024 titled "From Targets to Rewards: Continuous Target Sets in the Algorithmic Search Framework."

His competitive achievements are remarkable, having won first place in the Citadel Data Open Global Championship ($100,000 prize), first place in the Data Open 2021 West Coast ($10,000 prize), and the IMC Prosperity 2 trading challenge ($25,000 prize) with his team. He also placed 4th in the Terminal Global Championship 2022 and was among the top performers in the Berkeley Trading Competition.

Alan's professional experience includes internships at Jump Trading as a research intern (Summer 2024), Jane Street as a trading intern (Summer 2023), and Crabel Capital Management (part-time). He is also the founder and leader of the Caltech Quant Finance Club.

In 2021, Alan was selected for the prestigious NSF Graduate Research Fellowship, recognizing his potential to advance knowledge and benefit society. He describes himself as someone who "loves to meet and compete with the brightest minds," reflecting his passion for intellectual challenges and collaborative innovation.

In his free time, Alan enjoys playing badminton and table tennis, balancing his intense academic and professional pursuits with recreational activities.

short_description: Computer vision specialist with extensive experience in object detection and tracking systems. Zeeshaan has worked across healthcare, fintech, and security sectors, developing AI solutions that have significantly improved operational efficiency and accuracy. Zeeshaan Mohammed is a specialized Machine Learning Engineer with deep expertise in computer vision and AI systems implementation. His professional journey spans multiple industries where he has consistently delivered impactful AI solutions.

At Solo Tech, he spearheaded the development of advanced object detection and tracking systems using YOLO and Bytetrack, achieving a 30% improvement in accuracy while reducing irrelevant ID switches in challenging conditions. His optimization work reduced model inference latency by 40%, enabling effective edge-device deployment.

In the healthcare sector at Medtronic, Zeeshaan enhanced the GI Genius intelligent endoscopy AI system, achieving a 20% improvement in detecting precancerous lesions. He also developed a machine learning model for a smart insulin pen that reduced hypoglycemic events by 28% through personalized dosing recommendations.

His security-focused work at SkyLark Labs included deploying a real-time theft detection system with 90% accuracy that cut security response time in half, and designing a face recognition system achieving 95% accuracy through effective data augmentation techniques.

Earlier in his career at PayPal, Zeeshaan developed a churn prediction model that reduced customer attrition by 20%, retaining over 20,000 customers. He also deployed an NLP-based chatbot system that increased ticket resolution efficiency by 25%.

Zeeshaan holds a Master of Science in Computer Science from California State University, Los Angeles (2022-2024) and a Bachelor of Engineering in Computer Science from Muffakham Jah College of Engineering & Technology (2016-2020). He has supplemented his formal education with certifications in Deep Learning and Computer Vision, Natural Language Processing, Time Series Data Analysis, and Data Science from Udemy.

His technical expertise spans computer vision, machine learning, deep learning frameworks (particularly YOLO, DeepSort, and LSTM architectures), and data science methodologies, with a proven track record of translating technical capabilities into measurable business outcomes across diverse industry contexts.

name: george cheng
short_description: MIT student combining AI/CS with Brain & Cognitive Science, with research spanning neuro-symbolic learning, medical devices, and environmental engineering. Award-winning researcher and entrepreneur with publications in healthcare, pathogenic detection, and flood prediction, recognized by organizations including Regeneron ISEF and the Earth Prize.
long_description:
George Cheng is a multifaceted researcher and innovator currently studying Computer Science, Mathematics, and Finance at MIT. His academic journey bridges the gap between artificial intelligence and human cognition, with a particular focus on neuro-symbolic learning that mimics human brain architecture.

George's research portfolio is impressively diverse. At MIT CSAIL, he works on neuro-symbolic learning under PI Gerald Sussman. He previously conducted research at the MIT Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research, developing next-generation smart capsules for drug delivery. His work at MIT Sloan School of Management explored how AI can analyze monetary policy impacts on investment plans. At Westlake University, he developed an AI avatar called "Forever" that mimics human likeness using voice, pictures, and memory, which was recognized as "Best Idea" and "Best Project" at the Westlake University AI Open Course Project Showcase.

As an entrepreneur, George is a co-founder of Tally.AI, which helps researchers identify emerging studies and competing work, and was accepted into the Alchemist Accelerator with less than 1.7% acceptance rate. He's also involved with EWOR as a Fellow and has co-founded Stemable and Altra Co. as volunteer initiatives to address socioeconomic issues, raising $150,000 for homeless artists, cancer patients, and Title I schools.

His publication record includes papers on topics ranging from glucose monitoring devices to flood prediction models and machine learning applications for pathogenic detection. His project "FloodGate" won the Earth Prize, demonstrating his commitment to applying technology to environmental challenges. Another notable project, "PuriScan," uses machine learning for pathogen identification with a 3D-printable microscope that is 500x cheaper than commercial options and 750x faster than laboratory testing.

George's most personal research focuses on Type 2 diabetes, inspired by his mother's condition which developed during her pregnancy with him. He created an oral-fluid glucose-monitoring watch and later developed "DiaMiR," an insulin-delivering patch worn on the skin that delivers medication through painless microneedles. He has filed a provisional patent for this technology.

Beyond his technical work, George is an accomplished athlete, having been recognized as a Heisman High School Scholarship National Winner and participating in four varsity sports. He's also an Eagle Scout and World Science Scholar who has been recognized by numerous prestigious organizations including Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair (ISEF), National Junior Science and Humanities Symposium (JSHS), United States Stockholm Junior Water Prize, Coca-Cola, and the Department of Defense.

With his technical expertise spanning machine learning, MLLMs, AutoGPT, Stable Diffusion, GenAI, and various programming tools, George exemplifies excellence across multiple domains while maintaining a clear focus on using technology to solve meaningful problems, particularly in healthcare and environmental sustainability.

name: dylan nguyen
short_description: MIT '28 undergraduate researcher integrating control systems and Bayesian optimization for mRNA lipid nanoparticle manufacturing. Amazon Future Engineer Scholar with extensive experience in computational biology, neuroscience, and machine learning applications, having won multiple prestigious awards including 3rd Place at the International Science & Engineering Fair.
long_description:
Dylan Nguyen is a first-year undergraduate student at MIT (Class of 2028) with a remarkable background in computational biology, neuroscience, and AI research. Currently working as an Undergraduate Research Assistant at MIT Chemical Engineering, he's integrating control systems and Bayesian optimization for manufacturing mRNA lipid nanoparticles in the Myerson Research Group.

Dylan's research experience is impressive for his age. He has worked as a Scientific Programming Intern at the Max Planck Florida Institute for Neuroscience and has completed several significant research projects, including modeling the Drosophila Melanogaster nerve cord using spiking neural networks, applying deep learning to predict cytokines in Sickle Cell Anemia patients, and exploring machine learning for morphological neuron classification in the neocortex.

His academic achievements are equally notable. Dylan is an Amazon Future Engineer Scholarship recipient, which provides $40,000 towards college tuition and a guaranteed paid internship at Amazon. He's also a Kovner Opportunity Scholarship recipient, supporting talented public high school students to attend selective universities.

In competitive programming, Dylan has reached the Gold Division in the USA Computing Olympiad (USACO). His scientific research has earned him prestigious recognitions, including 3rd Place Grand Award in Biomedical and Health Sciences at the 2023 Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair, the Regeneron Biomedical Science Award, and finalist status at the National Junior Science and Humanities Symposium.

Currently, Dylan is also an AMP Scholar at Jane Street, where he's learning mathematics, computer programming, data analysis, and game theory. Previously, he participated in MIT's Introduction to Technology, Engineering, and Science (MITES) program, taking classes in Science Writing Communications and Regenerative Stem Cell Biology.

Beyond his academic pursuits, Dylan has ventured into entrepreneurship as a co-founder of Tally.AI, a startup that empowers researchers with AI-driven aggregation and analysis of scientific papers. Working alongside fellow MIT students and graduate students from other prestigious institutions, Tally.AI aims to prevent duplicative research efforts, enhance collaboration between research groups, and help researchers stay up-to-date with the latest works in their fields through features like similarity scoring, knowledge graphs, and real-time alerts.

Dylan's diverse projects demonstrate his versatility in applying computational methods across different domains, from neuroscience to financial trading, showcasing his ability to leverage AI and machine learning for solving complex problems in both research and entrepreneurial contexts.

name: olsen b.
short_description: Software Engineer at Affirm and MLH Top 50 recipient with expertise in workflow orchestration infrastructure and LLMs. Founded Hack@Davidson, Davidson College's first student-led hackathon, and has won multiple hackathon awards including 1st place at Caltech's HackTech. Currently consulting for Cognition to help improve Devin AI.
long_description:
Olsen B. (Oğuzhan Budanur) is a Software Engineer at Affirm working on the Workflow Orchestration Infrastructure Team, where he manages distributed systems integrating Airflow, Luigi, Spark, and Kubernetes that handle over 1,000,000 actions monthly. He developed a high-performance gRPC server in Kotlin and built a Slack bot leveraging semantic search and LLMs for efficient triage.

With a strong entrepreneurial spirit, Olsen founded and served as President of Hack@Davidson, organizing Davidson College's first student-led hackathon that raised over $6,000 and accommodated 90+ participants. His leadership extended to founding Competitive Coding at Davidson (C-CAD), which prepares members for software engineering jobs and internships. Under his guidance, the team won 11 prizes across 7 hackathons, including 1st place at Caltech's HackTech.

Olsen's professional experience includes working as a Software Consultant for Cognition AI Labs, helping to improve Devin AI, and founding Motate LLC, a boutique software contracting firm that secured multiple contracts and achieved quarterly revenue of ~$20,000. He also interned at Aptos Labs, where he created a 7,000-line open-source Python CLI for Kubernetes deployments that saved $70,000 through multithreading optimizations.

His technical expertise spans workflow orchestration, distributed systems, Kubernetes, Python, Kotlin, Java, C++, Firebase, and LLMs. Olsen is particularly passionate about building AI-powered tools, as demonstrated by his work on semantic search systems and LLM applications. He's recognized as part of the MLH Top 50 and has received multiple academic scholarships and hackathon awards, including wins for projects like WaitFree DMV, ImmiGrace, SusEats, BlockAide, and CodeViolet.

Olsen grew up in the DC Metro Area and discovered his passion for coding in middle school, starting with VisualBasic's GUI-based desktop apps. His love for technology was truly ignited at his first hackathon, VTHacks 7, in 2019. He studied Computer Science at Davidson College after transferring from Virginia Tech, where he was pursuing a double major in Computer Science and Computational Modeling & Data Analytics. He maintained a perfect 4.0 GPA in his major courses and served as a Teaching Assistant for a Blockchains class at Davidson College.

Beyond his technical work, Olsen enjoys exploring new technologies, participating in hackathons, and building innovative projects. His personal website at olsenbudanur.com showcases his portfolio of work and technical achievements.

name: debajyoti (debo) datta
short_description: Debajyoti (Debo) Datta is an experienced machine learning engineer and physician currently at Hippocratic AI with a background in building large-scale ML systems at AWS AI and Crossing Minds. He is an Amazon Research Fellow with expertise in TensorFlow and has contributed to open-source projects like Learn2learn for meta-learning research.
long_description:
Debajyoti (Debo) Datta has a unique dual career as both a machine learning specialist and a practicing physician. Currently working as a Co-Founder at Hippocratic AI, a healthcare-focused AI company that recently secured $141M in Series B funding, Debo brings valuable expertise to the healthcare AI sector.

His professional journey in AI includes significant roles at AWS AI and Crossing Minds, where he developed and implemented sophisticated machine learning solutions. In recognition of his contributions to the field, he was awarded the Amazon Research Fellowship in September 2022, highlighting his innovative approach to AI research.

As a physician, Dr. Datta is an Assistant Professor of Medicine at UCSF, specializing in Hematology and Oncology. He completed his MD at UCSF School of Medicine in 2012, followed by an Internal Medicine residency at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital (2012-2015) and a Hematology/Oncology fellowship at UCSF (completed in 2018). He also holds a PhD in Biophysics from UCSF (2010) and an undergraduate degree in Physics from Harvard University (2002).

His research work spans both fields, with publications in biomedical natural language processing, clinical data analysis, and AI applications in healthcare. He has contributed to projects like "PatientExploreR" for visualizing patient clinical histories and "ROMOP" for interfacing with electronic health record data. His recent work includes AI prediction of early relapse in lymphoma patients and analysis of treatment patterns in lung cancer.

Debo has a strong technical background in machine learning, particularly in large language models. He has contributed to significant AI research projects including BLOOM (a 176B-parameter multilingual language model) and has been cited thousands of times for his work on multitask prompted training and language model capabilities.

His competitive achievements include being part of the winning team at the Facebook Global PyTorch Hackathon in 2019, where he contributed to Learn2learn, a PyTorch library designed to make meta-learning more accessible. He also participated in the Allen NLP Hackathon 2021, focusing on recovering dataset errors and detecting model limitations through weak supervision.

Debo's academic excellence was recognized with the Ruthie Oxford Memorial Award from the Systems and Information Engineering Department at the University of Virginia in 2016, given to the most promising graduate student of the year.

His multilingual abilities include native proficiency in English and Bengali, along with professional working proficiency in Hindi, which enhances his collaborative capabilities in diverse teams.

Debo maintains an active interest in cutting-edge AI developments, particularly in reinforcement learning for language models, CUDA kernel optimization, and open-source AI initiatives as evidenced by his recent activity. His project "Open-Advice" suggests an ongoing commitment to knowledge sharing and community contribution in the AI field.

name: chandra suda
short_description: CS and Math student at Stanford University and Rise Global Fellow with a passion for social impact through technology. Specializes in AI applications in healthcare, with research experience at Harvard Medical School and innovative work on tuberculosis detection through cough audio analysis.
long_description:
Chandra Suda is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University (2024-2028) and a Rise Global Fellow with the Rhodes Trust, an initiative that selects 100 promising teens worldwide to support them as they work to solve humanity's most pressing problems.

With a strong focus on the intersection of AI and healthcare, Chandra has conducted significant research in applying machine learning to medical diagnostics. His most notable project involves developing an innovative app for early detection of tuberculosis using cough audio analysis. The app allows users to record a one-second cough segment and receive a diagnostic output, with plans to integrate healthcare provider notifications to help reduce disease spread. This work earned him recognition at the International Science & Engineering Fair, where he received a Grand Award in 2023.

Before attending Stanford, Chandra was a standout student at Bentonville High School in Arkansas, where he was accepted to multiple prestigious universities including Harvard, Princeton, Cornell, University of Pennsylvania, Johns Hopkins, Berkeley, Columbia, and Carnegie Mellon. His teachers describe him as intelligent, determined, studious, and notably humble, always expressing gratitude to educators who supported his journey.

Chandra currently serves as a Student Researcher at Harvard Medical School in AI and Medicine, and has previous experience as a Machine Learning Intern at Walmart Global Tech, where he worked on optimizing retail environment supply and inventory systems. He's also gaining experience in the AI startup ecosystem as a Founder Fellow at On Deck and Strategy Intern at Mercor, while working with Anthropic as a Stanford ambassador to strategize product growth efforts for Claude. Additionally, he serves as a Campus Strategist for Perplexity AI.

His technical achievements are complemented by leadership roles, including serving as the Red Cross Hub-Club President for the Missouri-Arkansas Region and leading the MissingMaps team to optimize disaster relief through geographical data mapping. At 16, he founded Aimate, a STEM education nonprofit, and has received US Presidential and Congressional Award recognitions for his humanitarian volunteer work.

As a published researcher with works on "Early Diagnosis and Predictive Treatment Monitoring of Tuberculosis With Novel Machine Learning Cough Analysis" and "Improving Alzheimer's Disease Diagnosis Using MRI Scans-Based Artificial Neural Networks," Chandra demonstrates a commitment to leveraging AI for meaningful social impact, particularly in healthcare accessibility and diagnostics for underserved communities.

name: soham vasanawala
short_description: Soham Vasanawala is a Mathematics student at Stanford University with a strong focus on the intersection of AI and healthcare. He has co-founded two startups, including Intratalent AI and Gains Coach LLC, where he's developing AI-powered coaching platforms. His research experience spans medical mixed reality and algorithm development for medical procedures, with notable presentations at ISMRM 2023.
long_description:
Soham Vasanawala is a Mathematics undergraduate at Stanford University with entrepreneurial drive and technical expertise in AI applications for healthcare and biotech.

As a co-founder of Intratalent AI (since November 2024) and Gains Coach LLC (since December 2021), Soham demonstrates his entrepreneurial spirit. At Gains Coach, he's developing a real-time, AI-powered coaching platform for various physical movements including physiotherapy, sports, fitness, and dance.

His research experience is impressive for his age. During his internship at Stanford University School of Medicine, he worked with the Incubator for Medical Mixed and Extended Reality, developing a real-time augmented-reality visualization of knee motion from MRI data for the HoloLens2. At Stanford University School of Engineering, he designed and conducted research that led to a time-saving algorithm for a medical procedure, which he presented at Stanford BioX 2022 and ISMRM 2023.

Notably, at ISMRM 2023, he presented research on "Predicting MR Image Quality from Breathing Patterns" where he demonstrated that detected breathing patterns could be utilized to predict whether adequate MR image quality would be obtained. Using a K-means clustering algorithm, his work showed that 9 in 10 forty-second breathing waveforms could be correctly predicted as either resulting in high or low image quality, potentially saving time from unnecessary scans.

Soham has also gained industry experience as a Software Engineer at Turboprop, a fintech startup in Menlo Park. His academic background includes a Bachelor of Science degree from Stanford University (2023-2027) and previous education at Henry M. Gunn High School.

Beyond his technical work, Soham has contributed to a publication titled "Essays and Interviews with Bay Area Entrepreneurs" (September 2022), showing his interest in entrepreneurship. He is also a member of The International Society for Magnetic Resonance in Medicine, further demonstrating his commitment to the medical technology field.

Soham is proficient in English (native) and has limited working proficiency in French. His diverse experiences in AI, healthcare technology, and entrepreneurship position him uniquely at the intersection of technology and medicine, with a particular focus on using AI to solve real-world healthcare challenges.

He appears to be related to Shreyas Vasanawala, MD/PhD, who serves as the William R. Brody Professor of Pediatric Radiology and Child Health at Stanford Medicine, suggesting a family connection that may have influenced his interest in medical technology.

name: rex liu
short_description: Undergraduate at Caltech pursuing Computer Science and Biology with a focus on Bio-inspired AI and Drug Discovery. Research Fellow at Thomson Lab developing innovative AI systems including thalamus-inspired LLM routers and GNN-based spatial proteomics. Currently interning at NASA JPL for the Lunar Trailblazer Spacecraft mission and competing on Caltech's Water Polo team.
long_description:
Rex Liu is an undergraduate student at Caltech studying Computer Science and Biology, with a particular focus on the intersection of these fields through Bio-inspired AI and Drug Discovery. As a Research Fellow at Caltech's Thomson Lab, Rex has developed several cutting-edge AI systems that demonstrate his innovative approach to machine learning.

His research portfolio includes a Thalamus-inspired LLM Router called "Herd" that creates scalable ensembles of small, open-source language models capable of outperforming larger proprietary models through Q-learning-based dynamic model selection. This work was presented at the NeurIPS Efficient Natural Language and Speech Processing Workshop. He's also worked on Hierarchical Chains with Multi-Level Abstention (HCMA), optimizing Black-box API deployments with uncertainty-based delegation and improved risk control, and published a paper on "Cost-Saving LLM Cascades with Early Abstention."

In the biomedical space, Rex has applied Graph Neural Networks to spatial proteomics, using counterfactual learning to identify tumor perturbations that enhance T-cell infiltration, with validated combinatorial therapies in collaboration with Cedars-Sinai. He's also worked on "Building Foundation Models to Characterize Cellular Interactions via Geometric Self-Supervised Learning on Spatial Genomics."

His most significant research contribution is on Functionally Invariant Path (FIP), a differential geometry-based framework that allows neural networks to adapt to secondary tasks without catastrophic forgetting. This groundbreaking work was published in Nature Machine Intelligence in 2024 and has already been cited by other researchers in the field. The FIP algorithm has wide-ranging applications from improving recommendations on online stores to fine-tuning self-driving cars.

Currently, Rex is interning at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, writing software for the Lunar Trailblazer Spacecraft as part of the Mission Operations and Ground Data Systems team. He is also a member of Caltech's Men's Water Polo team, competing as an Attacker.

Prior to Caltech, Rex worked as a research assistant at National Taiwan University's Systems Biology Epithelia Lab, where he designed a lethal Zika virus-driven plasmid for transgenic mosquitoes, expressing a hybrid neurotoxin upon Zika infection. He also integrated a protein BLAST search engine to identify sequence alignments in the lab's online databases.

Beyond his academic pursuits, Rex has extensive experience in cybersecurity, having worked as a Security Researcher at HackerOne and a Bug Bounty Hunter at Bugcrowd for over five years. He has also served as a Teaching Assistant at Taipei American School, instructing students in Mechanical Engineering (CAD, CNC, water jet cutting, TIG welding) and Modern Topics in Computer Science (logic gates, quantum mechanics, deep learning).

Rex's multidisciplinary background, spanning AI, biology, cybersecurity, and aerospace, positions him uniquely at the intersection of these rapidly evolving fields. He is fluent in Chinese and English, with working proficiency in Spanish and Japanese, further enhancing his ability to collaborate in global research environments. Outside of his academic and research work, Rex plays the violin and guitar.

name: arnav adhikari
short_description: 19-year-old EECS and Finance student at MIT with a passion for building innovative solutions in fintech, robotics, and healthtech. First place winner at HackMIT 2024 with a nicotine cessation patch project, and currently working on semantic operators at MIT CSAIL while also running a stealth startup.
long_description:
Arnav Adhikari is a dynamic 19-year-old undergraduate at MIT pursuing a dual focus in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) and Finance. His technical interests span across multiple domains including fintech (payments, wealth management, AI analysts), robotics (collaboration and control), healthtech (LLM-aided care), and productivity tools. He describes himself as a "big proponent of automating the mundane" and believes that jobs should be automated to redirect human attention toward tasks requiring ingenuity.

Arnav has built an impressive track record of achievements. Most notably, he and his team won the First Place Grand Prize at HackMIT 2024 with their algorithmically-driven nicotine cessation patch. He's currently working as a Builder at MIT's prestigious Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL), focusing on semantic operators.

Entrepreneurially minded, Arnav is the Founder and CEO of a stealth startup that he's been running since January 2024. His previous experience includes work at Boston Consulting Group (BCM), Rice University, Stanford's Center for Artificial Intelligence in Medicine & Imaging (AIMI), and Harvard Medical School, demonstrating his ability to collaborate with top-tier institutions across academia and industry.

Arnav's research work is particularly notable in healthcare technology. He has worked on cardiac imaging interpretability and standardized cardiac measurements at BCM, Texas Children's Hospital, and Stanford AIMI, with his work being featured in Circulation by the American Heart Association in November 2023. He has also analyzed teamwork synergy for AI Surgical Robotic Coaches at Rice HCAIR and Harvard Medical School, and developed smarter irrigation and water management systems for the City of Southside Place in Houston.

His technical background is further strengthened by his experience in robot motion planning and control at Rice RobotPI, and his achievements as a retired USAJMO winner and USACO Gold Medalist. Arnav is also an author, having written the Cubronix Competitive Math Practice Book for charity, which was featured in the Houston Chronicle in January 2022.

Beyond his academic and professional pursuits, Arnav offers tutoring services in the Greater Houston area, specializing in math, science, engineering, and test preparation. He enjoys tennis, basketball, football, biking, the outdoors, and various forms of media entertainment.

Currently a freshman at MIT (class of 2028), Arnav graduated from Carnegie Vanguard High School in 2024 after previously attending Bellaire High School. He describes himself as someone who loves "learning and building fast," and is always open to discussing innovative ideas and groundbreaking technologies.

name: andrew ye
short_description: Stanford University undergraduate studying Mathematics and Computer Science with research focus on AI, particularly neural architectures and network compression. Published at NeurIPS 2023 and ICML 2024, with experience as a software engineering intern, teaching assistant, and visiting instructor.
long_description:
Andrew Ye is a talented undergraduate student currently pursuing his B.S. in Mathematics and Computer Science at Stanford University, having transferred there in 2024. Prior to Stanford, Andrew studied at Case Western Reserve University from 2022 to 2024, also focusing on Mathematics and Computer Science.

Andrew has built an impressive research portfolio in artificial intelligence. Since June 2023, he has been working as an Undergraduate Researcher at the Case School of Engineering at Case Western Reserve University, collaborating with Dr. Shuai Xu, Dr. Vipin Chaudhary, and researchers at Rice AI and MIT. His research has led to publications at prestigious AI conferences including NeurIPS 2023 and ICML 2024, with his work "GNNs also deserve editing, and they need it more than once" receiving multiple citations.

Andrew's research interests span several areas of AI including neural architectures, human-computer interaction, probability/combinatorics, metacognition, and learning theory. He is particularly focused on addressing key questions in AI such as ensuring system faithfulness and security, balancing the scale-bloat tradeoff in neural networks, and understanding how neural networks fundamentally reason and learn. He founded quant@CWRU, a student-led research group supported by professors at Case Western Reserve University focused on integrating machine learning paradigms to solve complex financial tasks.

Beyond research, Andrew has gained practical industry experience as a Software Engineering Intern at Zventus from May to August 2023, where he worked with Angel Alban on healthcare technologies. He has also developed his teaching skills as a Teaching Assistant at Case Western Reserve University, where he assisted with courses in Algorithms and Discrete Mathematics from August 2023 to May 2024. Most recently, he served as a Visiting Instructor at DigiPen Institute of Technology, teaching Data Analytics and Statistics during the summer of 2024.

Andrew grew up in Seattle and Hong Kong and has diverse personal interests including solving puzzles, playing piano (with a particular fondness for Liszt), hiking with his dog, and writing on his blog. His commitment to community service is evident from his volunteer work with North Helpline from May 2021 to April 2022. His academic profile, research contributions, and diverse experiences showcase his versatility and dedication to advancing the field of artificial intelligence.

name: yohannes tenagashaw aklilu
short_description: Electrical Engineering student at Stanford University with diverse experience spanning aerospace, hardware engineering, and venture capital. Currently serving as a General Catalyst Venture Fellow while working at Amazon on ML quantization for embedded hardware and contributing to research at Stanford's PinCS Lab.
long_description:
Yohannes Tenagashaw Aklilu is an Electrical Engineering student at Stanford University (2023-2027) with a remarkable breadth of technical and business experience. His technical expertise spans multiple domains, with a particular focus on the intersection of hardware and machine learning.

Currently, Yohannes serves as a General Catalyst Venture Fellow while working as a Hardware Engineer at Amazon in Sunnyvale, CA. At Amazon, he focuses on quantization of DNN models to be deployed on accelerators like NNA and MDLA for firmware applications such as Alexa. His work involves creating automated frameworks for NNA.3x aware training to avoid floating point numbers and transform to fixed point numbers, as well as extending frameworks to support TensorFlow model quantization and converting compatible audiotech models into firmware.

Yohannes is actively engaged in research at Stanford University's Department of Computer Science, specifically in the PinCS Lab (Pedagogy in Computer Science Lab) where he works as an Undergraduate Researcher building drones. His aerospace interests extend to his earlier work as a Student Researcher at NASA, where he tested Aerogel insulation against radiation at 70,000 feet using weather balloon capsules.

His academic involvement at Stanford includes participation in the Leland Scholars Program, where he contributed to a research project titled "Equity in AI: Navigating Bias Through a Human-Centric Framework," analyzing approaches and implementing a paradigm shift for unbiased and ethical artificial intelligence.

Prior to Stanford, Yohannes worked as a Software Engineer at the Regional Transportation Commission of Southern Nevada, where he developed quantitative predictive modeling for city car crash data. He also conducted research at the University of Las Vegas Nevada for the International Science Fair, publishing work on "Analysis of Supersonic Parachutes On ReEntry" that examined crucial aspects of parachute design for rocket capsule reentry at supersonic speeds.

Yohannes possesses an impressive array of technical skills including machine learning frameworks (TensorFlow, PyTorch, Keras), programming languages (Python, C++, Java), hardware tools (Raspberry Pi, PCB design), robotics, computer vision (OpenCV), and data analysis tools (NumPy, Pandas, Matplotlib, Scikit-learn). His expertise also extends to aerospace engineering, mechatronics, embedded systems, and sensor fusion.

Based in both Palo Alto, CA and Las Vegas, NV, Yohannes represents a unique blend of technical depth across hardware engineering, aerospace, machine learning optimization, and venture capital experience - making him a versatile contributor to the AI and technology ecosystem.

name: wanzin yazar
short_description: AI researcher at d-Matrix and UC Berkeley alumnus specializing in LLM optimization. Published work on quantized LLMs and attention span acceleration for inference. Award-winning hackathon participant with expertise in cloud computing, deep learning, and healthcare AI applications.
long_description:
Wanzin Yazar is a Staff ML Research Engineer at d-Matrix, a company focused on in-memory compute architecture for AI applications, and is an alumnus of the University of California, Berkeley, where they earned a Bachelor's degree in Applied Mathematics with a focus on AI. Their research focuses on optimizing large language models (LLMs) for more efficient inference and deployment.

Wanzin has published several significant papers in the field of AI optimization, including "Post Training Quantization of Large Language Models with Microscaling Formats" (2024), "Self-Selected Attention Span for Accelerating Large Language Model Inference" (2024), "Understanding the difficulty of low-precision post-training quantization of large language models" (2024), and "Scaling laws for post-training quantized large language models" (2024). Their work demonstrates expertise in model quantization and inference acceleration techniques, which are critical for deploying AI models in resource-constrained environments.

Beyond LLM optimization, Wanzin has also contributed to research in healthcare AI applications, with publications like "Through the Looking Glass: Unraveling the Stage-Shift of Acute Rejection in Renal Allografts" (2022) and "The self-upgrading mobile application for the automatic malaria detection" (2020). At Nephrosant, Inc., they developed productionized machine learning models from large healthcare datasets, showing versatility in applying AI to solve real-world problems in the medical field.

Wanzin previously worked as a Machine Learning Researcher at UC Berkeley's Division of Computing, Data Science, and Society, focusing on deep learning-based recommender systems and student enrollment predictions using clustering practices and regression models. They also gained experience at Advancers.ai before joining d-Matrix.

Wanzin has an impressive track record in hackathons, winning the Grand Prize at AngelHack Silicon Valley 2019, Best Mobile Hack at SF HACK 2019, and the Best Asian Pacific Quest in the 2019 IBM Call For Code Global Challenge. These achievements highlight their ability to rapidly prototype and implement AI solutions.

Their professional certifications include Google Cloud Certified Data Engineer (issued January 2020), the Deep Learning Specialization from deeplearning.ai (issued January 2018), and Full Stack Machine Learning on AWS from AI Camp. name: zhizhuo z. zhou
short_description: Zhizhuo is a PhD student at Stanford University working at the intersection of Generative AI and 3D computer vision. Previously affiliated with IBM and Carnegie Mellon University, they have also contributed to AI education as a Lead TA for AI4ALL at CMU.
long_description:
Zhizhuo Z. Zhou is a PhD student in Computer Science at Stanford University, working in the Gradient Spaces Lab under the advisorship of Professor Iro Armeni. His research focuses on 3D generative AI, particularly understanding and generating 3D scenes from casual videos, images, and text.

Prior to Stanford, Zhizhuo was an MSR (Master of Science in Robotics) student at Carnegie Mellon University, where he worked with Professor Shubham Tulsiani. He completed his undergraduate studies at the University of Michigan, where he had the opportunity to work with Professor David Fouhey.

Zhizhuo's research contributions include several significant publications in top computer vision conferences. His recent work "MVD-Fusion: Single-view 3D via Depth-consistent Multi-view Generation" was accepted at CVPR 2024, proposing a novel depth-aware 3D attention mechanism for generating multi-view consistent RGB-D images from a single RGB image. Another notable publication, "SparseFusion: Distilling View-conditioned Diffusion for 3D Reconstruction" (CVPR 2023), introduced a 3D neural mode-seeking formulation that combines probabilistic generation of unseen regions with faithful reprojection of seen regions in a consistent 3D representation.

His earlier work includes "Quantifying Bird Skeletons" presented at the CV4Animals Workshop in conjunction with CVPR 2021, which demonstrated how deep learning can be used to measure bird skeleton specimens with extraordinary accuracy and speed, potentially unlocking datasets at unprecedented scales.

Zhizhuo has been recognized with several awards, including the NSF Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP) from 2021-2024. He also won the Meta-AI CO3D Challenge few-view reconstruction track at the ECCV 2022 NGR-CO3D workshop and received the Best Paper Award at the ProjectX 2020 ML for Climate Change Competition.

Beyond his research, Zhizhuo has demonstrated a commitment to AI education, serving as the Lead Teaching Assistant for AI4ALL at Carnegie Mellon University in 2022 and as a Project Mentor for AI4ALL at the University of Michigan in 2021. These experiences highlight his dedication to nurturing the next generation of AI talent through mentorship and education.

His publications have garnered significant attention in the field, with his work cited hundreds of times according to Google Scholar. Zhizhuo's unique specialization in combining generative AI with 3D technologies positions him at the forefront of creating more immersive and interactive AI-powered experiences.

name: radostin cholakov
short_description: Award-winning AI researcher, Stanford University undergraduate in Computer Science, and Forbes 30 Under 30 honoree specializing in natural language processing, quantization of large language models, and deep learning architectures for tabular data. Published author with significant contributions to efficient matrix multiplications for LLMs and task-oriented dialogue systems.
long_description:
Radostin Cholakov is a distinguished young AI researcher currently pursuing undergraduate studies in Computer Science at Stanford University. His research focuses on innovative approaches to deep learning architectures, particularly for tabular data, dialogue systems, and large language model optimization.

As the author of "Distributional Quantization of Large Language Models," Radostin has developed novel methods for efficiently storing LLMs in 4-bit precision while maintaining performance comparable to full-precision models. His recent work on "Fast Matrix Multiplications for Lookup Table-Quantized LLMs" (2024) with collaborators from MIT and CMU introduces FLUTE, a flexible lookup table engine that can be 2-4x faster than existing GEMM kernels for LLM inference.

Radostin's contributions to task-oriented dialogue systems include developing models with auxiliary tasks for response selection, addressing limitations in text generation abilities of pre-trained language models. His paper "Efficient Task-Oriented Dialogue Systems with Response Selection as an Auxiliary Task" (2022) achieved state-of-the-art results on the MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset while using significantly fewer parameters than baseline models.

His work on the GatedTabTransformer has enhanced deep learning architectures for tabular modeling, showing significant improvements over existing solutions. Additionally, his research on "Transformers predicting the future" (2021) applies attention mechanisms to next-frame and time series forecasting, garnering significant citations in the field.

Radostin is also the creator of "AzBuki.ML," a machine learning platform for natural language processing specifically designed for Slavic languages.

His exceptional work has earned him numerous prestigious awards, including an Honorable Mention from AAAI and First Award by Mawhiba at Regeneron ISEF'23, Second Award at the European Contest For Young Scientists 2022, and Second award from ACM at Regeneron ISEF'22. In 2021, he was recognized in Forbes' "30 under 30" list and received the Presidential Award "John Atanasoff" for exceptional results in National IT Competitions.

Beyond his research, Radostin is actively involved in volunteer work with organizations like Google Developer Experts, Smile for Africa Foundation (where he serves as a Full-Stack Software Engineer), and Google Developers Group Sofia. His academic collaborations include work with prominent researchers from MIT, including Yoon Kim, Han Guo, and Jonathan Ragan-Kelley, as well as Eric Xing from CMU.

As the founder of RSG, Radostin continues to push boundaries in AI research while contributing to open-source projects and humanitarian causes.

name: ryan zhijie rong
short_description: Stanford CS '28 student with extensive research experience in machine learning, focusing on healthcare applications and AI fairness. Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas Winner and Stanford HAI Research Assistant who combines technical expertise with a passion for applying AI to solve real-world problems in healthcare, climate, and financial markets.
long_description:
Ryan Zhijie Rong is a Computer Science and Mathematics student at Stanford University with impressive accomplishments in machine learning research and software development. His research portfolio spans multiple prestigious institutions, including Stanford's Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI), where he's developing an AI writing assistant using OpenAI APIs, and Stanford's School of Medicine, where he trained machine learning models to predict Alzheimer's Disease onset with a focus on fairness across demographic groups.

Ryan currently serves as a Stanford Student Employee at the Stanford Digital Economy Lab (S-DEL), which is part of the Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI). This role allows him to contribute to research at the intersection of digital technology and economic systems, further broadening his experience in applying AI to real-world challenges.

His technical expertise extends beyond academia into industry applications. At UIUC's Intelligent Code Analysis and Testing lab, he developed deep learning networks for generating realistic Java bugs, demonstrating his skills in both AI and software engineering. His professional experience includes roles at Kos, where he works on bio signal processing algorithms, and previous positions at companies like Skylow, StoneWise, and MingXi Capital, where he gained experience in software development, drug discovery, and financial analysis.

As a standout achiever, Ryan has received numerous accolades, including being named a Microsoft Imagine Cup Americas World Finals Winner in 2023, winning the Stanford CS229 Machine Learning Course Best Project award (top 3 out of 400+ students), and earning the Jessica Lynn Saal Fellowship Award from Stanford's Institutes of Medicine Summer Research Program (top 5% of researchers). He's also demonstrated excellence in competitive settings, placing 1st in the 2024 Cornell Trading Challenge Systematic Equities and reaching the top 8 in Citadel's AI tower defense competition.

Ryan's project portfolio showcases his diverse interests in AI applications, including long-range weather forecasting with diffusion models, American Sign Language translation, reinforcement learning for race car driving, and various computer vision and classification systems. He's multilingual, speaking Chinese and English at a native level, with limited working proficiency in Spanish.

Beyond his technical pursuits, Ryan is actively involved in volunteering as an Outreach Director and Tutor for Academic Advancements and has participated in fundraising for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society. His unique combination of technical expertise, research experience, and commitment to applying AI for social good positions him as a promising innovator in the field of artificial intelligence.

Ryan can be contacted via his Stanford email at ryanrong@stanford.edu, and his official Stanford profile is available for academic and professional connections.

name: eric mao
short_description: Co-Founder of Linkd (YC X25), former MasterChef Australia contestant, and UPenn M&T student with a strong background in AI research. Eric has worked on diverse projects from carbon sequestration estimation to cognitive status prediction using machine learning, and is currently building people search solutions through Y Combinator's accelerator program.
long_description:
Eric Mao is a multifaceted entrepreneur and researcher at the intersection of technology, business, and culinary arts. As the Co-Founder of Linkd (YC X25), he's currently building people search solutions through Y Combinator's prestigious accelerator program. His product has shown impressive early traction, with 18,000 users spending over 1,350 hours on the site within 48 hours of launch.

Eric was previously enrolled in the Jerome Fisher Program in Management & Technology (M&T) at the University of Pennsylvania, pursuing a dual degree in Computer Science and Business Administration at Wharton. He's currently on leave to focus on his startup.

His research experience spans multiple AI applications. He has worked on machine learning approaches for carbon credit accuracy, deep learning for 3D printing reliability enhancement, cognitive status prediction from fMRI data, and mind-controlled wheelchairs for ALS patients. His research on carbon sequestration earned him the Best Research Poster award at the International Conference on Climate Change in 2024.

Eric gained national recognition as a contestant on Season 13 of MasterChef Australia at the age of 21. As one of the youngest competitors, he showcased his passion for regional Chinese cuisine and Pan-Asian cooking. His culinary journey began early - he had previously auditioned for Junior MasterChef Australia at age 10. With roots in Wuxi, Eastern China, Eric's cooking is deeply influenced by his heritage and family traditions. During the competition, he created signature dishes including Shanghai Chive Pancake with Black Garlic Prawns, Three Treasure Wonton, and Strange Flavour Chicken.

Before MasterChef, Eric was a medical student at the University of New South Wales, where he made the difficult decision to defer his studies to pursue his culinary passion. His dream has been to create a pop-up restaurant that brings regional Chinese cuisine into a modern Australian setting.

Eric was also selected as a Fellow at Telora, where he worked on Iris, an improved file management system for video editors. His entrepreneurial journey includes participation in Z Fellows, a program for founders and builders.

During his high school years at Crescent School, Eric demonstrated exceptional talent in physics and computer science, representing Team Canada in the International Young Physicists' Tournament, earning a Gold Medal in the Canadian Young Physicists' Tournament, winning the High School Big Data Challenge, and reaching the Platinum Division in the USA Computing Olympiad (USACO).

Eric combines technical expertise in AI and machine learning with business acumen, entrepreneurial drive, and culinary creativity, focusing on creating practical solutions to real-world problems across multiple disciplines.

As a researcher at Stanford Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HAI), he applies his expertise in computational neuroscience to advance human-centered AI systems. Behind the camera, Matthew has written and directed multiple short films in his "True Story" series, which explores mental health issues through a noir therapy drama format. His short film "True Story: God Tells Bad Jokes" won the award for best short narrative at the 2023 Pan African Film & Arts Festival, qualifying it for Academy Awards consideration. He has also created immersive cinematic experiences combining film, live theater, and music that have sold out multiple shows in Los Angeles.

Matthew's activity on LinkedIn reveals his engagement with various AI communities and events, including defense hackathons, agent-based AI systems, and vector databases. He frequently collaborates with other talented individuals in both the AI and entertainment spaces.

name: neil movva
short_description: Neil Movva is a machine learning and computer architecture expert currently at Together AI. Previously, he co-founded Blyss, worked at Apple on the Neural Engine, and held positions at NVIDIA. He holds BS and MS degrees in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University.
long_description:
Neil Movva is a technology professional specializing in the intersection of deep learning and computer architecture. He currently works at Together AI, a company focused on artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies.

Neil's career has been marked by significant contributions to AI hardware and infrastructure. Before joining Together AI, he co-founded Blyss with Samir Menon in 2022, a Y Combinator-backed startup (W23 batch) focused on end-to-end encrypted AI. Blyss developed technology to run AI workloads in GPU-based secure enclaves, keeping data encrypted even during processing. The company also created an SDK for private information retrieval with strong cryptographic guarantees.

Prior to Blyss, Neil worked at Apple on the Neural Engine project, contributing to on-device AI inference capabilities. He also spent two summers at NVIDIA in the Deep Learning Architecture group, optimizing CUDA implementations for training large models at maximum speed. Additionally, he interned at Built Robotics, where he helped design an autonomous vehicle's perception system.

Neil holds both Bachelor's and Master's degrees in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University, where his coursework focused on AI/ML algorithms, computer vision, and graphics. His academic research included work on light fields, computational photography, and vision-based robotic autonomy. He has published research on topics such as dynamic field of view in tomographic light field displays.

Throughout his education, Neil demonstrated exceptional talent in scientific research. As a high school junior at Harker School, he placed 2nd at the Northern California/Western Nevada Junior Science and Humanities Symposium (JSHS) in 2014 with his project "A Novel Use of IR Light in Eye Tracking Systems," which proposed an efficient and cost-effective way to use eye movements to control computers. He was also recognized as a 2014 Siemens Research Competition Individual Semifinalist for his work on periodontal ligament morphogenesis.

Neil describes himself as someone who has "spent his whole career making computers go fast, especially for deep learning." He is passionate about large-scale compute and democratizing computational power. In his free time, he designs embedded electronics for robotics and manages a small-scale server farm optimized for high-performance computing.

name: dhruv gautam
short_description: Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science student at UC Berkeley specializing in AI research with a focus on interpretability, safety, reinforcement learning, and code generation. Currently a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR) and a former research intern at Microsoft, he combines academic excellence with practical experience in developing advanced AI systems.
long_description:
Dhruv Gautam is a Computer Science undergraduate at UC Berkeley (2022-2025) who has established himself as a promising researcher in the field of artificial intelligence. His research interests center on neural network interpretability, reinforcement learning, code generation, and AI safety - areas critical to the responsible development of advanced AI systems.

Currently, Dhruv works as a researcher at Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research (BAIR), focusing on interpretability and safety challenges in AI systems. He previously completed a research internship at Microsoft Research, where he worked on post-training techniques, code generation, and agents, contributing to research that is being presented at prestigious conferences including ICLR 2025 and NeurIPS 2024.

His research publications include "RefactorBench: Evaluating Stateful Reasoning In Language Agents Through Code" (ICLR 2025, OWA @ NeurIPS 2024), where he was a lead author alongside collaborators from Microsoft. He's also working on papers currently under review, including "WebGauntlet: Measuring Instruction Following and Robustness for Web Agents" and "SSEAL: Self-Supervised Explorative Agent Learning," the latter of which won 1st Place in the UC Berkeley LLM Agents Hackathon.

Before joining BAIR, Dhruv worked at Berkeley's SkyLab on consensus and distributed systems research. He has also contributed to academic life at Berkeley as a Course Staff member for CS70 in the Electrical Engineering & Computer Sciences department.

Beyond his formal research roles, Dhruv is actively involved in student organizations. He works on creative ML projects with Launchpad at UC Berkeley and explores cryptography with Blockchain at Berkeley. He has also volunteered with the Berkeley Math Tournament.

Dhruv's academic excellence is highlighted by multiple achievements, including four-time qualification for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME), the ASDRP Award for Excellence in Research, and The Leadership Award from the Cal Alumni Association.

Multilingual and multifaceted, Dhruv is fluent in English and Hindi with professional working proficiency in Spanish, reflecting his global perspective and communication skills that complement his technical expertise in AI research.

For professional inquiries, he can be reached at dhruvgautam@berkeley.edu.

name: aaquib syed
short_description: AI researcher at Google with a focus on interpretability and language model behavior. Aaquib has published significant work on refusal mechanisms in LLMs, attribution patching for circuit discovery, and efficient pruning techniques for massive language models. A Banneker-Key Scholar at the University of Maryland with a strong competitive programming background.
long_description:
Aaquib Syed is an AI researcher currently working at Google while affiliated with the University of Maryland, where he is pursuing a CS and Math degree as a Banneker-Key Scholar (full merit scholarship for the top 0.5% of incoming class). His research focuses on understanding and improving large language models, with particular emphasis on interpretability and model behavior mechanisms.

His recent publication "Refusal in Language Models Is Mediated by a Single Direction" (NeurIPS 2024, Poster) has garnered significant attention with 98+ citations. This groundbreaking work demonstrates that refusal behavior in conversational LLMs is controlled by a one-dimensional subspace across multiple open-source chat models, providing important insights into how safety mechanisms function in these systems.

Aaquib has also made significant contributions to automated interpretability research with his work "Attribution Patching Outperforms Automated Circuit Discovery" (BlackboxNLP at EMNLP 2024), which has received 47+ citations. In this paper, he developed a simple yet powerful method based on attribution patching that outperforms existing approaches while requiring minimal computational resources - just two forward passes and a backward pass.

In the area of model efficiency, his research "Prune and Tune: Improving Efficient Pruning Techniques for Massive Language Models" (ICLR TinyPapers Workshop 2023, top 6%) advanced techniques for pruning large language models without extensive retraining, addressing critical compute expense issues in deploying massive models.

His most recent work includes "Mechanistic Unlearning: Robust Knowledge Unlearning and Editing via Mechanistic Localization" (2024), exploring techniques for targeted knowledge editing in language models.

Beyond pure AI research, Aaquib has applied machine learning to medical imaging, co-authoring a paper in PLOS ONE that uses XGBoost with MRI and non-imaging data to predict pathological complete response in breast cancer patients undergoing neoadjuvant chemotherapy.

As a student, Aaquib has received numerous prestigious recognitions, including the USA Computing Olympiad Gold rank and the National Merit Scholarship. He has also developed several projects including a Personal Distance Monitor, a Stress Level Manager for students with autism spectrum disorder, and a FIRST Robotics Competition Scouting system.

According to his GitHub profile, Aaquib describes himself as someone who enjoys "thinking about and solving problems in AI/ML and finance" with a current interest in "creating scalable methods to attribute and edit behaviors and knowledge in large language models." He also mentions a love for competitive programming, working with low-level languages, and creating infrastructure and trading strategies for financial markets.

His interests span AI/ML and finance, with a particular focus on solving complex problems at the intersection of these fields. Aaquib's combination of theoretical research and practical applications demonstrates his versatility and depth of expertise in artificial intelligence.

name: ally nakamura
short_description: Recent Stanford graduate currently building at PearX and involved with Catapult AI. Ally has a background in deep learning, AI, and scientific research, with notable achievements including a gold medal at the International Earth Science Olympiad, selection as a Masason Foundation Scholar, and research on Chinese censorship.
long_description:
Ally Nakamura is a recent Stanford University graduate with BS/MS degrees in Computer Science with a focus on AI. She is currently building at PearX while also being involved with Catapult AI, where she's working on helping medical device companies deploy AI to make their workflows easier.

Her academic journey has been complemented by her deep interest in artificial intelligence and healthcare technology. She holds a Neural Networks and Deep Learning certification from deeplearning.ai and has worked with Stanford's Open Virtual Assistant Lab to build EHR-Xamine, a virtual assistant for electronic clinical health records designed to reduce physician burnout.

Ally has demonstrated exceptional scientific aptitude, having published research on Fluorescence-Guided Surgery in Frontiers in Oncology, where she reviewed applications of fluorescent probes in defining tumor locations during surgical procedures. Her scientific excellence was recognized internationally when she represented the United States at the International Earth Science Olympiad, earning a gold medal and ranking among the top 15 students out of nearly 400 participants from over 30 countries.

Her technical accomplishments include leading an AI-enabled email client at DoNotPay that was featured by Forbes and Wired, and building a voice agent to automatically handle reference checks for healthcare staffing agencies. She also enjoys participating in hackathons, where she has built AI dating apps and launched an AI crypto coin that scaled to $15M market cap.

Beyond her technical work, Ally has conducted significant research on Chinese censorship. Working with Jeffrey Shen, she created CensorScout and the Weibo Censorship Dashboard, two applications that increase transparency into censorship on Weibo. Their published paper on SSRN made daily top-tens in several sections and was in the top 10% of authors by downloads in the year following publication. This project was completed as part of Digital Propaganda & Censorship, an Independent Project at Phillips Academy.

Her entrepreneurial spirit is evident through her involvement with various organizations at Stanford, including co-founding the Stanford Chapter of Scholar of Finance and being a member of the Asia-Pacific Student Entrepreneurship Society. She also served as an intern at Stanford Women in Business, showcasing her interest in the intersection of business and technology.

Ally was selected as one of just 42 students to join the prestigious Masason Foundation after a rigorous three-round admissions process, further highlighting her exceptional potential. During her high school years, she contributed to STEM education as an Event Coordinator for Techstravaganza with Tomorrow's Women in Science and Technology.

She is bilingual in English and Japanese with limited working proficiency in German, giving her a global perspective that complements her technical skills and entrepreneurial mindset. In her free time, she enjoys hiking, attending DJ sets, eating sushi, and playing poker with friends.

name: prady saligram
short_description: Deep learning researcher at Stanford AI Lab (SAIL) and mathematics & computer science student at Stanford University. Specializes in optimizing language models and developing financial technology applications, with experience in quantitative research, entrepreneurship, and technical leadership.
long_description:
Prady Saligram is a deep learning researcher at Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) and a mathematics and computer science student at Stanford University. His research focuses on implementing and optimizing language models, particularly working on RoBERTa in Jax and Haliax within Stanford's Levanter framework, and developing novel PoS tagging fine-tuning methods for historical languages under Professor Christopher Manning.

At Stanford's Advanced Financial Technologies Lab, Prady is developing an end-to-end pipeline for a proprietary LLM using a hybrid dense-sparse RAG framework to process 10-K filings, with a focus on enabling accurate time series forecasting of financial metrics. His work spans constructing domain-specific datasets, creating evaluation benchmarks, and optimizing embedding retrieval for deductive reasoning.

Beyond his research, Prady serves as Vice President of Hackspace at the Business Association of Stanford Entrepreneurial Students (BASES), where he organizes weekly hacker hours, themed hackathons, and faculty speaker series. Under his leadership, Hackspace has become a technical hub for builders, providing mentorship opportunities and collaborating with Microsoft Founder's Hub to offer compute credits and other resources to student projects. He also helped build Founder Pact, a co-founder matching platform that gained popularity on campus.

Prady was selected for the Battalion Fellow Incubator Program with a competitive acceptance rate of less than 7% and has gained industry experience through internships at Citadel Securities as a Quant Invitational Wintern and at Al-Futtaim as a System Engineering Intern. He also co-founded Voice Maths, a platform enabling users to find answers to math-related questions, managed by a team of accredited student tutors.

His academic achievements include a 4.14/4.0 GPA at Stanford, where his coursework spans theoretical statistics, applied matrix theory, PDEs, real analysis, machine learning, NLP with deep learning, and computer systems. Prior to Stanford, he earned 44/45 points in the International Baccalaureate program and was awarded the Claes Nobel Legacy Award from the National Society of High School Scholars.

Outside of academics, Prady is passionate about tennis, staying active, and enjoys Stanford's large campus which necessitates long bike rides and walks. He is proficient in multiple programming languages including Python, JavaScript, React, C++, and has experience with machine learning frameworks. As a self-described "project-oriented learner at heart," he continues to explore the future of LLMs, mathematical reasoning, and blockchain technology.

name: joe qiaoyun li
short_description: CS and EE student at Stanford University with a diverse research background spanning machine learning, power electronics, and biosignal processing. Currently a Machine Learning Researcher at Nous Research focusing on pre-training LLMs and reinforcement learning for reasoning models. Former USA IOI Training Camp participant with experience in compiler development at Moffett.AI.
long_description:
Joe Qiaoyun Li is a Computer Science and Electrical Engineering student at Stanford University with an impressive research portfolio across multiple technical domains. Currently working as a Machine Learning Researcher at Nous Research, he focuses on pre-training large language models and developing reinforcement learning techniques for reasoning models.

Joe's research experience is remarkably diverse for his age. At the Hawaii Digital Health Lab, he conducted groundbreaking work on biosignal-based emotion recognition using AI, resulting in a first-authored publication in JMIR AI. His research at Princeton Power Electronics Lab led to multiple publications in IEEE journals and conferences, including innovative work on magnetic core loss modeling using neural networks and multi-material power magnetics modeling with machine learning frameworks.

His technical versatility extends to his work as an ML Compiler at Moffett.AI, where he gained practical experience in compiler development. Earlier in his academic journey, Joe contributed to computer vision and autonomous planning research at Carnegie Mellon University's Search-based Planning Lab.

Beyond his research accomplishments, Joe has demonstrated leadership as Co-President of TeamsCode and as Founder and President of ParagonX Academy. His academic excellence is highlighted by his selection as valedictorian at The Harker School, where he completed advanced coursework in mathematics, physics, and computer science.

Joe's competitive achievements are equally impressive, having been selected for the USA IOI Training Camp as one of the top 25 students nationwide, earning a USA Physics Olympiad Gold Medal (top 40 nationally), and qualifying for the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME) five times.

His publication record includes four peer-reviewed papers across different domains, showcasing his ability to apply machine learning techniques to solve complex problems in fields ranging from healthcare to power electronics. His first-authored paper in JMIR AI compared personalized and generalized approaches to emotion recognition using consumer wearable devices, while his IEEE publications focus on power magnetics modeling and characterization using advanced machine learning frameworks.

According to Google Scholar, Joe's research has already garnered 22 citations, with his JMIR AI paper on emotion recognition receiving 14 citations and his work on DC-bias injection methods for power magnetics characterization receiving 7 citations. This early citation record demonstrates the impact and relevance of his research contributions.

Joe also offers mentorship services to high school students, providing guidance on olympiad preparation, research opportunities, and college applications, drawing from his own experiences as a successful applicant to top universities like Stanford and MIT.
